Under these conditions, psychological and interpersonal stressors will take on added importance in affecting the safety of the crew and the outcome of the mission.</excerpt>

title: Biological and cognitive determination of the gravitational reference frame
doc: <title>Biological and cognitive determination of the gravitational reference frame</title> <excerpt>It is argued that space sickness is not so much a physiological problem, but a psychological one, having its roots in the perception of the environment, and its associated cognitive processing. This cognitive processing is argued to be that of field dependence and field independence, for which exist psychobiological and cognitive assessment tests.</excerpt>

title: An outbreak of illness among aerospace workers
doc: <title>An outbreak of illness among aerospace workers</title> <excerpt>A multispecialty panel of physicians evaluated a case series of 53 composite-materials workers in a large aircraft manufacturing facility who filed workers' compensation claims for illness labeled by the media as the 'aerospace syndrome'. Possible skin and respiratory tract exposures included formaldehyde, phenol, particulates, epoxy resins, and trace organic solvents, but measured concentrations were well below all regulatory and consensus standards.</excerpt>

title: Effects of β1- and β2-blockade on blood pressure and sympathetic responses to flight phobia stress
doc: <title>Effects of β1- and β2-blockade on blood pressure and sympathetic responses to flight phobia stress</title> <excerpt>Cardiovascular and sympathoadrenal effects of short-term oral treatment with β<inf>1</inf>-blockade (atenolol, 50 mg, administered two times) and β<inf>2</inf>-blockade (ICI 118,551, 50 mg, administered three times) were compared with placebo during actual flying in subjects with flight phobia (n = 34). β<inf>1</inf>-Blockade lowered resting blood pressure and heart rate and prevented a heart rate response but not a blood pressure response to this psychologic stress.</excerpt>

title: A psychosocial and biomedical comparison between men in six contrasting service occupations
doc: <title>A psychosocial and biomedical comparison between men in six contrasting service occupations</title> <excerpt>A study of psychosocial job factors and physiological states was conducted using 150 men, aged between 25 and 60, working in six widely different occupations—freight handlers, aircraft mechanics, air traffic controllers, physicians, waiters and symphony musicians. The aim of the study was to characterize any differences in physiological parameters in relation to differences in psychosocial job characteristics.</excerpt>

title: The ergonomic evaluation of eye movement and mental workload in aircraft pilots
doc: <title>The ergonomic evaluation of eye movement and mental workload in aircraft pilots</title> <excerpt>This paper presents an experiment which examines characteristics of pilots’ scanning behaviour when using integrated CRT displays, and the changes in characteristics when pilots face abnormal situations. The subjects were five experienced pilots.</excerpt>

title: Anomie, alcohol abuse and alcohol consumption: A prospective analysis
doc: <title>Anomie, alcohol abuse and alcohol consumption: A prospective analysis</title> <excerpt>Cross-sectional and 36-month prospective analyses of the relationships among anomie and both alcohol abuse and alcohol consumption patterns provided little support that anomie was directly associated with ethanol ingestion patterns in a sample of 302 male air traffic controllers. This lack of association was observed for self-reported alcohol consumption, interview-established alcohol abuse and biochemical markers of alcohol intake.</excerpt>

title: Cardiovascular response patterns and speech: A study of air traffic controllers
doc: <title>Cardiovascular response patterns and speech: A study of air traffic controllers</title> <excerpt>The present study examined the relationship between cardiovascular (CVS) response and speech among air traffic controllers (ATCs). During two one-hour work sessions continuous EKG, ear pulse, and audio recordings were obtained individually from 24 male ATCs.</excerpt>

title: Psychomotor screening for USAF pilot candidates: Selecting a valid criterion
doc: <title>Psychomotor screening for USAF pilot candidates: Selecting a valid criterion</title> <excerpt>Subjects for this research were 153 prospective pilots who were tested on computerized versions of the Two Hand Coordination (2HC) and Complex Coordination (CC) psychomotor tests. Independent variables included five basic error scores associated with the two psychomotor tests.</excerpt>

title: Marijuana, aging, and task difficulty effects on pilot performance
doc: <title>Marijuana, aging, and task difficulty effects on pilot performance</title> <excerpt>This study provides evidence that diverse factors can cumulatively contribute to human/machine performance decrements. In separate sessions, young and old pilots smoked one of three cigarettes containing either 0 mg, 10 mg, or 20 mg of the active ingredient, delta 9 THC.</excerpt>

title: Application of airline pilots' hours to junior doctors.
doc: <title>Application of airline pilots' hours to junior doctors.</title> <excerpt>OBJECTIVE--To determine the staff required if the rules for airline pilots' hours of work are applied to junior doctors. DESIGN--Junior anaesthetists recorded their workload from 1 March 1988 to May 31 1988.</excerpt>

title: Effects of Daily Workload on Subsequent Behavior During Marital Interaction: The Roles of Social Withdrawal and Spouse Support
doc: <title>Effects of Daily Workload on Subsequent Behavior During Marital Interaction: The Roles of Social Withdrawal and Spouse Support</title> <excerpt>This article examines daily variability in 2 marital behaviors, social withdrawal and the expression of anger, as a function of daily taskload at work. Thirty-three air traffic controllers (ATCs) and 27 wives completed surveys on 3 consecutive days.</excerpt>

title: Effects of space travel on sexuality and the human reproductive system.
doc: <title>Effects of space travel on sexuality and the human reproductive system.</title> <excerpt>This paper discusses the possible effects space travel may have on the human reproductive system and on human sexuality..</excerpt>

title: The highlights, and the lows, of aviation medicine in the 1940's: the human element.
doc: <title>The highlights, and the lows, of aviation medicine in the 1940's: the human element.</title> <excerpt>This article describes the experience and knowledge gained by the author during an extensive study tour of the majority of aviation medicine centres in the United Kingdom, Canada, and the United States in 1942. The emphasis is upon the human element rather than the technical, and the contribution of thousands of scientists from medical, psychological, and allied disciplines whose dedication was vital to air supremacy.</excerpt>

title: Growing Up in America: White, Male, and Medically Limited
doc: <title>Growing Up in America: White, Male, and Medically Limited</title> <excerpt>A subject that must be heavy on the mind of every pediatrician and pediatric cardiologist is “who should care for adults with congenital heart disease.” Whoever takes on this challenge also must accept responsibility to work as an advocate for this population and to focus on the areas of health insurance and employment opportunity and rights. The article written by Mr.</excerpt>

title: Type A, amicability and injury: A prospective study of air traffic controllers
doc: <title>Type A, amicability and injury: A prospective study of air traffic controllers</title> <excerpt>Recent research has suggested that only a subset of Type A's may be at higher risk for negative health outcomes. The present prospective study of 416 air traffic controllers attempted to determine if a sub-group of Type A's who were disliked by their co-workers had significantly higher risk of injury than liked A's and all Type B's over a 27-month period.</excerpt>

title: Multidimensional scaling analysis of simulated air craft combat maneuvering performance data
doc: <title>Multidimensional scaling analysis of simulated air craft combat maneuvering performance data</title> <excerpt>This paper describes the decomposition of air combat maneuvering by means of multidimensional scaling (MDS). MDS analyses were applied to performance data obtained from expert and novice pilots during simulated air-to-air combat.</excerpt>

title: Cognitive demands in automation
doc: <title>Cognitive demands in automation</title> <excerpt>As the nature of a task changes with increasing automation, so do the cognitive demands on the human operator. The present study examines the implications of such changes on subjective workload and automation design issues.</excerpt>

title: Simulator induced syndrome: Evidence for long-term aftereffects
doc: <title>Simulator induced syndrome: Evidence for long-term aftereffects</title> <excerpt>Pilots have experienced various adverse symptoms hours and even days following flight simulator training. This study surveyed pilots undergoing simulator training in an attempt to provide an initial gauge of the extent, severity, and possible risk factors of long-term (>1 day) simulator aftereffects.</excerpt>

title: Effects of high visual taskload on the behaviours involved in complex monitoring
doc: <title>Effects of high visual taskload on the behaviours involved in complex monitoring</title> <excerpt>A simulated air traffic control task was used to study the effects of prolonged monitoring on some of the behaviours (complex discriminations, interpretations, decisions, memory for actions taken) frequently associated with operational monitoring tasks, but seldom examined in laboratory vigilance studies. Forty-eight subjects performed the monitoring task under relatively high taskload conditions for 2h.</excerpt>

title: Selected papers from the Fourth Symposium on Aviation Psychology: I
doc: <title>Selected papers from the Fourth Symposium on Aviation Psychology: I</title>

title: USAF pilot selection and classification systems
doc: <title>USAF pilot selection and classification systems</title> <excerpt>A total of 478 pilot candidates were given a computerized test battery, the Basic Attributes Test (BAT) currently being validated for pilot selection and classification. The battery included tests of psychomotor and cognitive/perceptual abilities and personality/attitudinal characteristics.</excerpt>

title: Trends in Poland in space psychology research
doc: <title>Trends in Poland in space psychology research</title> <excerpt>This paper discusses the basic directions of research carried out in Poland during the years 1981-86 within the Polish Academy of Science project 06.7. The subject matter concerns: individual and situational determinants of human functioning in stress conditions; functioning of a human in extreme conditions; and load imposition through activities requiring risk-taking decisions..</excerpt>

title: Space vehicle approach velocity judgments under simulated visual space conditions
doc: <title>Space vehicle approach velocity judgments under simulated visual space conditions</title> <excerpt>There were 35 volunteers who responded when they first perceived an increase in apparent size of a collimated, two-dimensional perspective image of an Orbiter vehicle. The variables of interest included the presence (or absence) of a fixed reticle within the field of view (FOV), background starfield velocity, initial range to the vehicle and vehicle closure velocity.</excerpt>

title: Personal characteristics related to accident histories of Canadian pilots
doc: <title>Personal characteristics related to accident histories of Canadian pilots</title> <excerpt>Over 8,800 returns of a questionnaire, distributed to Canadian pilots, were analyzed. Items were chiefly about life events, hobbies, humour, and characteristics which might bear on susceptibility to 'pilot error' accidents.</excerpt>

title: Communication as group process mediator of aircrew performance
doc: <title>Communication as group process mediator of aircrew performance</title> <excerpt>This study of group process was motivated by a high-fidelity flight simulator project in which aircrew performance was found to be better when the crew had recently flown together. Considering recent operating experience as a group-level input factor, aspects of the communication process between crewmembers (Captain and First Officer), were explored as a possible mediator to performance.</excerpt>

title: Passenger fear of flying: Behavioural treatment with extensive in-vivo exposure and group support
doc: <title>Passenger fear of flying: Behavioural treatment with extensive in-vivo exposure and group support</title> <excerpt>The techniques used in the treatment of passenger fear of flying are described. They include behaviour modification techniques (relaxation, systematic desensitization, and cognitive restructuring), and educational programme, high in-vivo exposure, and group support.</excerpt>

title: Cognitive performance deficits in a simulated climb of Mount Everest: Operation Everest II
doc: <title>Cognitive performance deficits in a simulated climb of Mount Everest: Operation Everest II</title> <excerpt>Cognitive function as stimulated altitude was investigated in a repeated-measures, within-subject study of performance by seven volunteers in a hypobaric chamber, in which atmospheric pressure was systematically lowered over a period of 40 d to finally reach a pressure equivalent to 8,845 m, the approximate height of Mount Everest. The portable cognitive test battery used, Automated Performance Test System (APTS), was specifically designed for field research under adverse environmental conditions as evidenced by compact computer design; automated test administrations, data storage, and retrieval; psychometric properties of stability and reliability; and factorial richness.</excerpt>

title: The visually guided control of simulated altitude
doc: <title>The visually guided control of simulated altitude</title> <excerpt>Simulated 'flights' over three different ground textures were used to examine people's ability to extract optical information useful for active regulation of altitude. The textures were regularly spaced lines as follows: 1) orthogonal to the direction of flight (latitude texture); 2) parallel to the direction of flight (meridian texture); and 3) both parallel and orthogonal (square texture).</excerpt>

title: A simulator-based approach to training in aeronautical decision making
doc: <title>A simulator-based approach to training in aeronautical decision making</title> <excerpt>The effectiveness of a simulator-based approach to training pilot skills in risk assessment and decision making was evaluated in a sample of pilots enrolled in a university aviation science program. The 16 experimental group subjects received 4 hours (h) of classroom instruction designed to enhance pilot judgment skills, followed by 4 simulated cross-country flights during which several critical inflights events occurred.</excerpt>

title: Communication indices of crew coordination
doc: <title>Communication indices of crew coordination</title> <excerpt>The relationship between communication patterns and performance in 10 two-person flightcrews is explored with the aim of identifying speech variations which differentiate low- and high-error full mission simulator flights. Verbal data, transcribed from the videotaped performances, are treated as interactive sequences of speech events in which statements spoken by one crewmember are considered within the context of the other crewmember's prior and subsequent speech.</excerpt>

title: The giant hand phenomenon
doc: <title>The giant hand phenomenon</title> <excerpt>The 'giant hand' is a form of recognized spatial disorientation. An experienced fighter pilot described the events leading up to ejection from his out-of-control aircraft.</excerpt>

title: Sources of stress affecting pilot judgment.
doc: <title>Sources of stress affecting pilot judgment.</title> <excerpt>The initial stages of our research on the effects of the overassessment or underassessment of the consequences of nonroutine events (a potentially important factor in decision-making by pilots) is described. Critical difficulties in the measurement of life stress are discussed and a partial solution is suggested in the form of the Life Events Questionnaire (LEQ), an instrument on which individuals report the nature of stressful events, when they happened, and how much they concern them at the time of testing.</excerpt>

title: Pre-escape and escape aircraft maneuvers and gyrations: A critical under-reported problem affecting escape system performance and aircrew safety
doc: <title>Pre-escape and escape aircraft maneuvers and gyrations: A critical under-reported problem affecting escape system performance and aircrew safety</title> <excerpt>A major problem confronting both the requirements formulators and the designers of aircrew escape systems is defining the systems' operational emergency conditions. For years the community has relied on computerized complications of such data.</excerpt>

title: The time course of postflight simulator sickness symptoms
doc: <title>The time course of postflight simulator sickness symptoms</title> <excerpt>Reports of posteffects following training sessions in Navy and Army flight simulators were obtained from pilots to determine the time course of recovery from simulator sickness. Results imply that posteffects may be a more serious problem than previously considered; 45% of all those queried (N > 700) reported having experienced symptoms of simulator sickness; 25% of the symptoms lasted more than 1 h after leaving the simulator; and 8% lasted more than 6 h.</excerpt>

title: Ascertaining the causal factors for 'ejection-associated' injuries
doc: <title>Ascertaining the causal factors for 'ejection-associated' injuries</title> <excerpt>Determining the cause(s) for an ejectee's injuries is one of the more important and yet most difficult tasks associated with an ejection investigation. Selection of causal factors is often distorted by rumors and inaccurate teaching concerning how specific types of injuries occur and/or the consequences of using specific types of Aircrew Automated Escape Systems (AAES) and Aircrew Life Support Systems (ALSS) equipment.</excerpt>

title: Geographic disorientation: Approaching and landing at the wrong airport
doc: <title>Geographic disorientation: Approaching and landing at the wrong airport</title> <excerpt>Geographic disorientation in aviation operations results from the failure of an aircrew to recognize and/or maintain the desired position relative to the external ground and airspace environment. Becoming lost during flight, intruding inadvertently into unauthorized airspace, selecting a wrong airway, landing on the wrong runway, and approaching the wrong airport - with or without actual landing - are some examples of inflight geographic disorientation.</excerpt>

title: Triazolam impairs learning and fails to improve sleep in a long-range aerial deployment
doc: <title>Triazolam impairs learning and fails to improve sleep in a long-range aerial deployment</title> <excerpt>Of the soldiers deployed from the 18th Airborne Corps, Ft. Bragg, NC, on the Army's annual field exercise in the Middle East (Operation Brightstar) 68 received either placebo or 0.5 mg of triazolam once airborne on the first leg of their journey from the U.S.</excerpt>

title: Failing aviator syndrome: A case history
doc: <title>Failing aviator syndrome: A case history</title> <excerpt>The 'human factor' has long been recognized as the cause, or the contributing cause, of most aircraft mishaps. Frequently, the mishap aviator may be overstressed emotionally to the point that he makes errors of judgment, either by omission or commission.</excerpt>

title: Treatment of essential hypertension with yoga relaxation therapy in a USAF aviator: A case report
doc: <title>Treatment of essential hypertension with yoga relaxation therapy in a USAF aviator: A case report</title> <excerpt>A 46-year-old Caucasian male USAF aviator with a 6-year history of mild essential hypertension (medical waiver for flight duty) under unsuccessful treatment with hydrochlorothiazide, dietary modification, and exercise, was subsequently trained in yoga relaxation. After 6 weeks, medication had been discontinued, and his diastolic blood pressure remained within normal levels.</excerpt>

title: The effects of window shape and reticle presence on performance in a vertical alignment task
doc: <title>The effects of window shape and reticle presence on performance in a vertical alignment task</title> <excerpt>This study was conducted to evaluate the effect of selected interior work-station orientational cuing upon the ability to align a target image with local vertical in the frontal plane. Angular error from gravitational vertical in an alignment task was measured for 20 observers viewing through two window shapes (square, round), two initial orientations of a computer-generated space shuttle image, and the presence or absence of a stabilized optical alignment reticle.</excerpt>

title: Behavioural science and outer space research
doc: <title>Behavioural science and outer space research</title> <excerpt>This paper notes the awakening interest of NASA in the potential inclusion of behavioural scientists in the U.S. space programme, but expresses the fear that unless a major shift occurs in the attitudes of some key personnel the outcome might not be as promising as otherwise possible.</excerpt>

title: Soviet space flight: The human element
doc: <title>Soviet space flight: The human element</title> <excerpt>Building on past experience and knowledge, the Soviet manned space flight effort has become broad, comprehensive, and forward-looking. Their long-running space station program has provided the capabilities to investigate long-term effects of microgravity on human physiology and behavior, and test various countermeasures against microgravity-induced physiological deconditioning.</excerpt>

title: Becoming a flight surgeon
doc: <title>Becoming a flight surgeon</title> <excerpt>This text is the inaugural lesson given by the Professor of Aeronautic Psychiatry and starts the training period for new flight surgeons in the French Air Force. Introducing the French Air Force Medicine Training Session, the author speaks about the psychological aspects in aviation medicine.</excerpt>

title: An Israeli Airforce mental health unit: sociopsychological factors and medical care use following psychological intervention.
doc: <title>An Israeli Airforce mental health unit: sociopsychological factors and medical care use following psychological intervention.</title>

title: USING FULL-MISSION SIMULATION FOR HUMAN FACTORS RESEARCH IN AIR TRANSPORT OPERATIONS.
doc: <title>USING FULL-MISSION SIMULATION FOR HUMAN FACTORS RESEARCH IN AIR TRANSPORT OPERATIONS.</title> <excerpt>This study examined state-of-the-art mission-oriented simulation and its use in human factors research. Guidelines were developed for doing full-mission human factors research on crew member behavior during simulated air transport operations.</excerpt>

title: Managing flying phobia
doc: <title>Managing flying phobia</title>

title: Age and airline accidents
doc: <title>Age and airline accidents</title> <excerpt>The issuance of a commercial pilot's license is contingent upon the fulfillment of stated minimum flight time. These requirements imply that total flight time and aircraft flight time can be equated with safety.</excerpt>

title: Mental stress: 'occupational injury' of 80s that even pilots can't rise above.
doc: <title>Mental stress: 'occupational injury' of 80s that even pilots can't rise above.</title>

title: Effects of deprivation on smokers' mood during the operation of a complex computer simulation
doc: <title>Effects of deprivation on smokers' mood during the operation of a complex computer simulation</title> <excerpt>Research has shown that smoking reduces mood fluctuation in smokers and deprivation of smoking leads to mood change. The purpose of this study was to assess the effects of three hours of deprivation and subsequent smoking on mood in smokers while operating a computer simulation of an air traffic controller's job in a 2 × 2 (Deprived vs Nondeprived × Nicotine vs Nicotine Free Cigarettes) factorial design.</excerpt>

title: Cabin staff's perception of the impact of flying on their physical health
doc: <title>Cabin staff's perception of the impact of flying on their physical health</title> <excerpt>The impact on physical health of a long-term career in the cabin service sector of commercial airlines is not as yet well documented. For those in aviation medicine there is obviously a need to be aware of any physical effects which may occur, to enable them to provide appropriate advice.</excerpt>

title: Sleep and wakefulness of the airline plot
doc: <title>Sleep and wakefulness of the airline plot</title> <excerpt>There are two overriding concerns in the design of schedules for aircrew who have to cope with irregularity of their sleep due either to work at unusual times of the day or to time zone changes. The first is that aircrew must be able to achieve an acceptable sleep pattern, and this is likely to involve short periods of sleep and naps.</excerpt>

title: Ethical problems of interaction between ground-based personnel and orbital station crewmembers
doc: <title>Ethical problems of interaction between ground-based personnel and orbital station crewmembers</title> <excerpt>Manned missions onboard orbital stations Salyut-6 and Salyut-7 have led us to the conclusion that a long-term space mission can be viewed as a complex socio-man-machine system whose effectiveness largely depends on the quality of interaction between its subsystems. When analyzing and assessing the reliability of this system, it is important to consider ethical aspects, because they concern human relations, permeating its very component and in the long run determining its efficiency.</excerpt>

title: The recruitment and organizational integration of space personnel
doc: <title>The recruitment and organizational integration of space personnel</title> <excerpt>This paper describes the philosophy of selection of astronaut scientists. It deals mainly with psychological selection criteria oriented at the job demands.</excerpt>

title: Adult children of alcoholics - A treatable entity: An aviation case report
doc: <title>Adult children of alcoholics - A treatable entity: An aviation case report</title> <excerpt>This is a case report of a male naval aviator, raised in an alcoholic environment, and the impact of that environment on his development and adult functioning. title: Military flight experience and sympatho-adrenal activity
doc: <title>Military flight experience and sympatho-adrenal activity</title> <excerpt>Urine excretion levels of adrenaline (A) and noradrenaline (NA) were determined, and achievement, commitment to the task, difficulty, risk, activation, and tension were rated after the preparation or planning and after the performance of 245 missions by 21 attack pilots. title: The psychological health and stress of pilots in a labor dispute
doc: <title>The psychological health and stress of pilots in a labor dispute</title> <excerpt>This study investigated the psychological stress and psychiatric symptomatology in a representative sample of pilots involved in a labor dispute with management. title: Simulator induced syndrome in Coast Guard aviators
doc: <title>Simulator induced syndrome in Coast Guard aviators</title> <excerpt>The incidence of adverse symptoms in Coast Guard aviators undergoing flight simulator training was determined. A voluntary, multi-part questionnaire was completed by 238 pilots.</excerpt>

title: A scale for the estimation of sleep problems in clinical research
doc: <title>A scale for the estimation of sleep problems in clinical research</title> <excerpt>Problems in sleeping are widely prevalent in modern society and are often one of the presenting complaints of patients consulting physicians. In addition, there is scattered epidemiologic evidence and considerable clinical support that disturbed or inadequate sleep may be a risk factor for clinical emergence of cardiovascular disease and for total mortality.</excerpt>

doc: <title>Pilot's attitudes toward alcohol use and flying</title> <excerpt>Questionnaires were sent to a national sample of licensed pilots. Respondents reported their flying experience and their drinking behavior.</excerpt>

doc: <title>Flight surgeon support of combat operations at RAF Upper Heyford</title> <excerpt>Flight surgeon support of the Libyan Air Strike on April 14-15, 1986 is reviewed. title: Aircrew selection systems
doc: <title>Aircrew selection systems</title> <excerpt>Research was conducted to develop and validate a computerized battery of psycomotor and cognitive tests to identify candidates who sould not either complete pilot training or be recommended for a fighter assignment after training. All or part of the battery of 15 tests was given to 1,622 Air Force Pilot candidates prior to training and their test scores were regressed against various flying performance measures.</excerpt>

title: Motion sickness and anxiety

title: The aviation psychology program at RAF Upper Heyford
doc: <title>The aviation psychology program at RAF Upper Heyford</title> <excerpt>An Aviation Psychology Program was started in September, 1985 at RAF Upper Heyford, with the focus on teaching flight commanders and their wives to recognize and deal with aircrew member and family stress. title: Neuropsychiatric observations of proprioceptive sensitivity in motion sickness susceptibility
doc: <title>Neuropsychiatric observations of proprioceptive sensitivity in motion sickness susceptibility</title> <excerpt>The assessment of motion sickness susceptibility is still an unsolved problem, due in part to its unclear etiology. doc: <title>Type a behavior pattern and illness other than coronary heart disease</title> <excerpt>The paper presents three independent studies. Two are retrospective and one prospective.</excerpt>

doc: <title>The right and wrong stuff in civil aviation</title> <excerpt>Aircrewmembers (ACMs) enter a mortally hostile environment when they take off from Earth in their flying machines. title: Post accident/incident counseling: Some exploratory findings
doc: <title>Post accident/incident counseling: Some exploratory findings</title> <excerpt>An examination of the literature, and other sources of information, suggested that there might be prophylactic value in early psychological intervention following crewmember involvement in stressful incidents. doc: <title>Changes in job strain in relation to changes in physiological state: A longitudinal study</title> <excerpt>A sample of 73 men and women aged 22-63 years and working in six different occupations (air traffic controllers, waiters, physicians, symphony orchestra musicians, baggage handlers, and airplane mechanics) participated in a longitudinal study four times during a year. doc: <title>Urinary cortisol excretion and mood ratings in aircraft cabin crew during a tour of duty involving a disruption in circadian rhythm</title> <excerpt>A psychophysiological study was carried out on 28 cabin crew, comprising two teams, who were to travel from Sydney to Los Angeles and return, with stopovers in Los Angeles of 58 and 82 hr respectively. doc: <title>The Prospective impact of psychosocial variables on rates of illness and injury in professional employees</title> <excerpt>From a prospective study of health changes in air traffic controllers, it was determined that high scores on self-report measures of work-related life change distress, other life changes outside the worksetting, the type A behavior pattern, and dissatisfaction with management were positively related to future rates of injuries and physician-diagnosed acute illness episodes. Depending on the risk factor involved, high scorers on these psychosocial risk predictors incurred from 80% to 252% more future accidental injuries and from 38% to 69% wore future total morbidity over a 27-month follow-up period than the men in the low scoring groups.</excerpt>

title: Circadian arrhythmia: Shiftwork, travel and health
doc: <title>Circadian arrhythmia: Shiftwork, travel and health</title> <excerpt>There are many reasons why employees' working hours may come into conflict with the inherent (circadian) rhythms of their bodies. Vital services such as police, ambulance, hospitals, electricity must be maintained 24 hours a day; expensive equipment is more profitable if used continuously; machinery such as furnaces may be damaged if shut down.Work patterns which conflict with our circadian rhythms may produce fatigue, a tendency to make errors, accident-proneness, 'jet-lag' and perhaps ill health.Those most at risk are shiftworkers and aircrew: whilst the latter must cope with changing shift patterns and time-zone changes, the former are required to adapt to changes in work/sleep patterns against an environmental background disruptive to such an adaptation.More difficulties arise when we consider those with chronic health problems since employees on long-term medication may not be able to reconcile an unvarying drug regimen to an ever-changing work pattern.</excerpt>

doc: <title>Cases from the aerospace medicine residents' teaching file: #6</title>

title: Truth telling, placebos, and deception: Ethical and legal issues in practice
doc: <title>Truth telling, placebos, and deception: Ethical and legal issues in practice</title> <excerpt>The issue of truth-telling is very complex. There is variance among patients in the amount of information they want to be told and variance among professionals in the amount of information they want to tell.</excerpt>

title: The effects of task performance on ocular accommodation and perceived size
doc: <title>The effects of task performance on ocular accommodation and perceived size</title>

title: The USAF pilot selection and classification research program
doc: <title>The USAF pilot selection and classification research program</title>

title: Pilot error as a symptom of inadequate stress coping
doc: <title>Pilot error as a symptom of inadequate stress coping</title> <excerpt>Over 700 psychological questionnaires, completed on naval aviators who had been involved in major aircraft mishaps over a 4-year period were divided into two groups. Those collected on aviators who were causally involved in their mishaps were compared with those who had no culpability in their mishaps.</excerpt>

title: Helicopter copilot workload during nap-of-the-earth flight
doc: <title>Helicopter copilot workload during nap-of-the-earth flight</title> <excerpt>Two automatic navigation systems, a Doppler radar system and a projected map system, and a hand-held map were examined for their effects on copilot/navigator workload and performance. The automatic navigation systems reduced the number of navigation errors and the size of deviations from intended track.</excerpt>

title: An analysis of crew co-ordination problems in commercial transport aircraft
doc: <title>An analysis of crew co-ordination problems in commercial transport aircraft</title> <excerpt>This paper describes a survey of co-ordination problems and attitudes amongst a sample of 250 commercial airline pilots. The results indicate that co-ordination problems are most likely when the workload is high.</excerpt>

title: The emotional consequences of ejection, rescue and rehabilitation in Royal Air Force aircrew
doc: <title>The emotional consequences of ejection, rescue and rehabilitation in Royal Air Force aircrew</title> <excerpt>Retrospective questionnaire information was sought from 175 Royal Air Force officers who had survived ejection from an aircraft and 88% replied. A profile of risk factors, both objective and subjective, was found in the 40% who subsequently experienced prolonged emotional disturbances.</excerpt>

title: Circadian rhythmicity and fatigue in flight operations
doc: <title>Circadian rhythmicity and fatigue in flight operations</title>

title: Cognitive problems in aviation psychological studies
doc: <title>Cognitive problems in aviation psychological studies</title>

title: Aviation safety - physical and mental incapacitation
doc: <title>Aviation safety - physical and mental incapacitation</title> <excerpt>There is a trend of continual improvement in flight safety and the best airlines flying the best aircraft are now achieving fatal accident rates of less than one in one million flying hours or flights. In this paper an overview is presented of the relationship of pilot age, physical incapacitation and mental disorders to accidents..</excerpt>

title: Personality and somatotype of trainee pilots
doc: <title>Personality and somatotype of trainee pilots</title> <excerpt>Personality and somatotype studies of pilots have mostly been restricted to military pilots and experienced airline crews. In this investigation of 16 PF and Heath-Carter somatotype method were utilized to study 31 male aviation majors, aged between 18 and 38 yr., who had earned their Private Pilots Licenses and were working toward more advanced ratings.</excerpt>

title: The American Institutes for Research
doc: <title>The American Institutes for Research</title> <excerpt>Reviews the development, research approaches, and focus of the American Institutes for Research, which was an outgrowth from the success of the Aviation Psychology Program in the US Army Air Forces in World War II. The organization was incorporated as a nonprofit agency to carry out research on problems for government, education, and industry.</excerpt>

title: Computer-aided testing of pilot response to critical in-flight events
doc: <title>Computer-aided testing of pilot response to critical in-flight events</title> <excerpt>This research on pilot response to critical in-flight events employs a unique methodology including an interactive computer-aided scenario-testing system. Navigation displays, instrument-panel displays, and assorted textual material are presented on a touch-sensitive CRT screen.</excerpt>

title: An investigation of the effectiveness of pilot judgment training
doc: <title>An investigation of the effectiveness of pilot judgment training</title> <excerpt>Pilot decisional errors have always been a significant factor in aviation accidents. Pilot judgment, however, traditionally has been viewed as an intrinsic quality or a by-product of flying experience.</excerpt>

title: Application of a multifactor approach to transfer of training research
doc: <title>Application of a multifactor approach to transfer of training research</title> <excerpt>A multifactor, multicriterion transfer of training experiment involving a computer-generated horizontal tracking task was conducted to establish relationships among training and transfer scores for manual control of a maneuvering vehicle, to determine the response surfaces for training and transfer, and to demonstrate a new transfer research paradigm that makes economically feasible the simultaneous investigation of the effects of a large number of training-equipment and use variables on transfer to multiple-criterion vehicle configurations. There were 80 experimental participants, 48 of whom were trained and tested on individually unique combinations of training and transfer conditions.</excerpt>

title: Cockpit management attitudes
doc: <title>Cockpit management attitudes</title> <excerpt>Distinctions are drawn between personality traits and attitudes. The stability of the personality and the malleability of attitudes are stressed.</excerpt>

title: A brief history of aviation psychology
doc: <title>A brief history of aviation psychology</title> <excerpt>This paper presents an overview of the field of aviation psychology from its pre-World War I beginnings to current problems and opportunities for today's aviation psychologists. This brief survey covers some of the more significant early activities of aviation psychologists in the United States and Europe..</excerpt>

title: Principles of S-C-R compatibility with spatial and verbal tasks: The role of display-control location and voice-interactive display-control interfacing
doc: <title>Principles of S-C-R compatibility with spatial and verbal tasks: The role of display-control location and voice-interactive display-control interfacing</title> <excerpt>A pilot's tasks may be categorized into those that demand predominantly verbal operations and those that are spatial. We describe two experiments that define two principles of compatibility of interfacing such tasks with displays and controls.</excerpt>

title: Dyads and triads at 35,000 feet: Factors affecting group process and aircrew performance
doc: <title>Dyads and triads at 35,000 feet: Factors affecting group process and aircrew performance</title> <excerpt>Discusses the small-group performance situation involved in the task of flying a multipilot transport aircraft and research psychology's problems in defining the nature of the group process. Input variables (eg, task characteristics, reward structure, position power, stress levels) have been identified and related to the flightcrew process.</excerpt>

title: NASA's life sciences and space radiation biology
doc: <title>NASA's life sciences and space radiation biology</title> <excerpt>Plans for the various missions in which men and women are expected to participate during the next 10 years are outlined. Such missions include flights of up to three months duration in low earth orbit as well as possible short excursions to geosynchronous orbit.</excerpt>

title: The use of constant routines in unmasking the endogenous component of human circadian rhythms
doc: <title>The use of constant routines in unmasking the endogenous component of human circadian rhythms</title> <excerpt>A major problem in the study of the internal clock(s) that drives human circadian rhythms is that due to the effect produced by rhythmicity of habits and external influences ("masking" A particularly potent factor in this respect is the sleep-wake cycle. It is anomalous that, even though this masking influence is widely accepted, most studies of circadian rhythmicity have been performed in the presence of such interferences.</excerpt>

title: The politics of stress: The case of air traffic control
doc: <title>The politics of stress: The case of air traffic control</title> <excerpt>Analysis of the 1981 Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization strike suggests that workers who employ the concept of stress to describe undesirable job conditions risk unexpected negative consequences. In deciding not to make subjective claims that can only be addressed in political terms, workers necessarily appeal to outside experts to provide scientific, objective descriptions of job conditions.</excerpt>

title: On the measurement of pilot perceptual workload: A comparison of assessment techniques addressing sensitivity and intrusion issues
doc: <title>On the measurement of pilot perceptual workload: A comparison of assessment techniques addressing sensitivity and intrusion issues</title> <excerpt>A flight simulator-based study was conducted to examine fourteen distinct mental workload estimation measures, including opinion, secondary task, physiological, and primary task measures. Both the relative sensitivity of the measures to changes in mental workload and the differential intrusion of the changes on primary task performance were assessed.</excerpt>

title: Synthesized warning messages: effects of an alerting cue in single- and multiple-function voice synthesis systems
doc: <title>Synthesized warning messages: effects of an alerting cue in single- and multiple-function voice synthesis systems</title> <excerpt>The present study examined the effectiveness of preceding synthesized voice warning messages with an alerting cue as a function of the amount of information presented by the voice synthesizer and the workload level in the primary task. Subjects performed a simplified air traffic control task in which they were required to monitor two visual displays and to enter commands via a standard keyboard.</excerpt>

title: Perceived threat and avoidance maneuvers in response to cockpit traffic displays
doc: <title>Perceived threat and avoidance maneuvers in response to cockpit traffic displays</title> <excerpt>Airline pilots rated their perception of the danger of an air-to-air collision based on cockpit displays of traffic information while they monitored simulated departures. They selected avoidance maneuvers when necessary for separation.</excerpt>

title: The use of relaxation/desensitization in treating anxiety associated with flying
doc: <title>The use of relaxation/desensitization in treating anxiety associated with flying</title>

title: The adaptability rating for military aeronautics: An historical perspective of a continuing problem
doc: <title>The adaptability rating for military aeronautics: An historical perspective of a continuing problem</title>

title: After the fire-ball
doc: <title>After the fire-ball</title>

title: Fear of flying: An Israeli Air Force short case report
doc: <title>Fear of flying: An Israeli Air Force short case report</title>

title: Effects of personality on body temperature and mental efficiency following transmeridian flight
doc: <title>Effects of personality on body temperature and mental efficiency following transmeridian flight</title>

title: Heart rate variability, cardiac mechanics, and subjectively evaluated stress during simulator flight
doc: <title>Heart rate variability, cardiac mechanics, and subjectively evaluated stress during simulator flight</title>

title: A comparison of rating scale, secondary-task, physiological, and primary-task workload estimation techniques in a simulated flight task emphasizing communication load
doc: <title>A comparison of rating scale, secondary-task, physiological, and primary-task workload estimation techniques in a simulated flight task emphasizing communication load</title> <excerpt>Sixteen potential metrics of pilot mental workload were investigated regarding their sensitivity to communication load and their intrusion on primary-task performance. A moving-base flight simulator was used to present three cross-country flights.</excerpt>

title: Personality profiles of pilots
doc: <title>Personality profiles of pilots</title> <excerpt>Samples of Air Force fighter pilots, trainee commercial pilots, and males drawn from the general community completed the Edwards Personality Preference Schedule (EPPS). Four significant effects were found for individual sub-scales; three (Achievement, Affiliation, and Nurturance) identifying air force fighter pilots.</excerpt>

title: Isolated sleep paralysis after rapid time zone change ('jet lag') syndrome
doc: <title>Isolated sleep paralysis after rapid time zone change ('jet lag') syndrome</title> <excerpt>Isolated sleep paralysis is the sudden inability to perform voluntary movements occurring at the onset of sleep or upon awakening during the night or in the morning. Consciousness remains clear, although dreamlike states of hallucinations may occur during the episode of paralysis.</excerpt>

title: The evolution and present status of mental health standards for selection of USAF candidates for space missions
doc: <title>The evolution and present status of mental health standards for selection of USAF candidates for space missions</title> <excerpt>The mental health evaluation of the original Mercury astronauts was a prolonged, meticulous, research-oriented process involving testing and interviews to determine who was best qualified for space flight. The trend since then has been to simplify this evaluation, making it more subjective and clinically oriented.</excerpt>

title: Psychiatric illness in military aircrew
doc: <title>Psychiatric illness in military aircrew</title> <excerpt>The selection and assessment of military aircrew depends on accurate information, which should be obtained not only from the pilot but also from his peers and his employer. Psychological reactions are related to interactions between the man, his task, and his environment, both service and personal.</excerpt>

title: Psychiatric disorders in civilian pilots
doc: <title>Psychiatric disorders in civilian pilots</title> <excerpt>Psychiatric disorders are second only to cardiovascular disorders as a cause of permanent loss of licence in both professional aircrew and private pilots in the UK. In professional aircrew, psychiatric disorders are commonly aviation-related, whilst in private pilots less effective selection and the stresses of business and personal affairs are common factors.</excerpt>

title: The human element in air traffic control: Aeromedical aspects, problems, and prescriptions
doc: <title>The human element in air traffic control: Aeromedical aspects, problems, and prescriptions</title> <excerpt>During periods of reduced visibility, air traffic controllers are the most critical factor in aircraft collision avoidance. Controllers also largely determine efficiency in the mass movement of aircraft on instrument plans.</excerpt>

title: Assaults in the air: Concerning attacks against flight attendants
doc: <title>Assaults in the air: Concerning attacks against flight attendants</title> <excerpt>Violence directed at airline personnel by passengers while an aircraft is in flight presents an interesting and uncommon form of deviant behavior that can inform the study of deviance in general. Such behavior has been identified by various observers as a growing social problem.</excerpt>

title: Anxiety and Coping Behavior During an Emergency Landing
doc: <title>Anxiety and Coping Behavior During an Emergency Landing</title> <excerpt>A flight from London to New York (the Titanic itinerary), presenting a flight crash on one of the screens and a film about the Titanic on the other, suddenly had a fire on board. The captain intended to make an emergency landing on the water near the spot where the Titanic disappeared.</excerpt>

title: Ait travel fatigue
doc: <title>Ait travel fatigue</title> <excerpt>Travel fatigue is a condition both acute and chronic, which occurs in the travelling public and also affects pilots and cabin crew. Much can be done to alleviate this condition, by modification of flight schedules and conditions during flight.</excerpt>

title: Predicting performance in aircrew
doc: <title>Predicting performance in aircrew</title> <excerpt>There can be little doubt that human error is a major causal factor in flying (and, indeed, other) accidents. This is particularly likely to be so in flying modern fighter aircraft.</excerpt>

title: HABITABILITY SUPPORT FOR MANNED MISSIONS OF SPACE 2000.
doc: <title>HABITABILITY SUPPORT FOR MANNED MISSIONS OF SPACE 2000.</title> <excerpt>This paper presents the concept of a habitability support subsystem consisting of those design elements needed to satisfy the psychological and social needs of the flight crews of advanced missions. Utilizing such a concept in the design of space vehicles will serve to emphasize and focus attention on spacecraft design features which in the past have been subservient to the more visible aspects of environmental control and life support.</excerpt>

title: Biofeedback monitoring-devices for astronauts in space environment
doc: <title>Biofeedback monitoring-devices for astronauts in space environment</title> <excerpt>After a reconsideration of the state-of-the-art in biofeedback research the implementation of biofeedback systems is envisioned as a countermeasure of stress for the psychoprophylaxis of the astronaut. A one-session experiment performed on two groups of subjects to assess the interference from EMG-feedback on the performance in a simultaneous psychomotor trial with a view to expanding biofeedback application is described.</excerpt>

title: Flight experience and naval aircraft mishaps
doc: <title>Flight experience and naval aircraft mishaps</title> <excerpt>Naval aircraft mishaps involving pilot error for a 5-yr period were analyzed to determine the specific underlying causes as functions of lifetime and recent experience. The data show that certain problems tend to manifest themselves at different levels of experience.</excerpt>

title: Psychological well-being in united states air force fliers
doc: <title>Psychological well-being in united states air force fliers</title> <excerpt>Three dimensions of overall health are defined by the World Health Organization-physical, mental, and social. Psychological well-being has been a popular research topic recently and has been shown to relate to mental health.</excerpt>

title: The journey out and in: Psychiatry and space exploration
doc: <title>The journey out and in: Psychiatry and space exploration</title> <excerpt>Although psychiatric issues have in theory always been considered important in space biomedical research, specific research into these issues has been severely limited because of other priorities that were more pertinent to the technological development of space flight capacity. As the technical and physical aspects of space flight become more routine, the psychological issues should take on increasing importance.</excerpt>

title: Cardiorespiratory assessment of 24-hour crash-diet effects on altitude, +Gz, and fatigue tolerances
doc: <title>Cardiorespiratory assessment of 24-hour crash-diet effects on altitude, +Gz, and fatigue tolerances</title> <excerpt>Eleven male surrogates of general aviation pilots, 21-35 years old, were tested for altitude, +Gz, and fatigue tolerances with and without previous fasting for 24 hr. Testing included 2 min of lower body negative pressure (LBNP) at-40 torr (equivalent to +2Gz) after 118 min at 3,810 m chamber altitude and, after returning to ground level pressure, ergometry of 50 watts (W) for 6 min.</excerpt>

title: Negative transfer: A threat to flying safety
doc: <title>Negative transfer: A threat to flying safety</title> <excerpt>Negative transfer is defined in the context of this paper as the transfer from one cockpit to another - of different design or configuration - of habits or responses which were appropriate in the former but are inappropriate in the latter, thereby posing a threat to flying safety. This danger has been demonstrated not only experimentally but also in a number of aircraft accident investigation reports.</excerpt>

title: Validation of a proposed pilot-trainee selection system
doc: <title>Validation of a proposed pilot-trainee selection system</title>

title: Landing airplanes, detecting traffic, and the dark focus
doc: <title>Landing airplanes, detecting traffic, and the dark focus</title> <excerpt>Misjudgements of position in flight and failures to detect other airbone traffic are casualties of the eternal tug-of-war between visible texture and the pilot's dark focus. The eye is lazy and resists the pull of a distant stimulus, preferring to rest at relatively short focal distance, as it does in the dark or when looking at the sky.</excerpt>

title: Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: III.
doc: <title>Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: III.</title>

title: An adaptive private pilot certification exam
doc: <title>An adaptive private pilot certification exam</title> <excerpt>Adapting aviation certification exams to each examinee's ability may reduce administration costs and increase the accuracy of certification decisions. Several means of adapting exams are based upon item response theory.</excerpt>

title: Motivational analysis of human volunteers for centrifuge acceleration research
doc: <title>Motivational analysis of human volunteers for centrifuge acceleration research</title> <excerpt>Motivational analysis of a representative group of individuals who volunteer to participate in centrifuge acceleration research at the USAF School of Aerospace Medicine was performed. Monetary reward and curiosity were the main reasons for volunteering to participate in the research program.</excerpt>

title: The influence of differential physical conditioning regimens on simulated aerial combat maneuvering tolerance
doc: <title>The influence of differential physical conditioning regimens on simulated aerial combat maneuvering tolerance</title> <excerpt>The influence of physical conditioning on tolerance to a centrifugation profile called the Simulated Aerial Combat Maneuvering (SACM) was determined using 24 young men as subjects. These subjects were assigned to groups as controls (no physical training, C), runners (R), and weight trainers (W).</excerpt>

title: Circadian rhythms and fatigue: A discrimination of their effects on performance
doc: <title>Circadian rhythms and fatigue: A discrimination of their effects on performance</title> <excerpt>Different effects between circadian rhythms and fatigue have been discriminated. The discrimination was based on human performance changes.</excerpt>

title: The role of communications, socio-psychological, and personality factors in the maintenance of crew coordination
doc: <title>The role of communications, socio-psychological, and personality factors in the maintenance of crew coordination</title> <excerpt>There is increasing evidence that many air transport incidents and accidents are the result of the improper or inadequate utilization of the resources accessible to flight deck crew members. These resources obviously include the hardware and technical information necessary for the safe and efficient conduct of the flight, but they also include the human resources which must be coordinated effectively.</excerpt>

title: A study of decision-making behavior of aircraft pilots deviating from a planned flight
doc: <title>A study of decision-making behavior of aircraft pilots deviating from a planned flight</title> <excerpt>This paper outlines an investigation into the worth structures of pilots facing a deviation from a planned flight. A 'paper and pencil' simulation was used to frame the situation into which pilots interjected their own decision-making skills in a simple ranking of candidate diversion airports with varying locational, navigational aid, radar, and weather attributes.</excerpt>

title: Sex as a moderator variable in the selection and training of persons for a skilled task
doc: <title>Sex as a moderator variable in the selection and training of persons for a skilled task</title> <excerpt>We gave 51 male and 52 female Air Force Academy Cadets a battery of five cognitive and three perceptual motor tests before they were taught four basic flight maneuvers followed by a complex chandelle maneuver. The results showed that the males were much faster in attaining the criterion level of performance on the flight tasks, and that some of the sex differences in the acquisition of task skills can be reduced by means of pretraining on specific cognitive and motor skills.</excerpt>

title: Instructional design for aircrew judgement training
doc: <title>Instructional design for aircrew judgement training</title> <excerpt>Aircrew training design has made significant progress during recent years. However, significant gaps exist both in design methodology and in existing skills.</excerpt>

title: Functional optical invariants: A new methodology for aviation research
doc: <title>Functional optical invariants: A new methodology for aviation research</title> <excerpt>The application to aviation physiology of Gibson's 'ecological approach to visual perception' demands information-rich visual displays to adequately and unambiguously enable a pilot to perform flight maneuvers. Optical information often takes the form of invariant properties of a changing optic array, and functional invariants are defined as psychologically effective optical invariants.</excerpt>

title: Towards an internal model in pilot training
doc: <title>Towards an internal model in pilot training</title> <excerpt>Optimal decision making requires an information seeking behavior which reflects the comprehension of the overall system dynamics. Research in the area of human monitors in man-machine systems supports the notion of an internal model with built-in experiences.</excerpt>

title: An analysis of aircrew procedural compliance
doc: <title>An analysis of aircrew procedural compliance</title> <excerpt>This research examines the relationships between aircrew compliance with procedures and operator errors. The data for this analysis were generated by reexamination of a 1976 experiment in full-mission simulation.</excerpt>

title: Emotional reactions to military aircraft accidents
doc: <title>Emotional reactions to military aircraft accidents</title> <excerpt>The author has had extensive experience responding to inflight emergencies and actual aircraft accidents, generally of fighter aircraft. This article considers the emotional effects of these events on family members within the squadron, on other squadron aircrew and their families, and on rescue and recovery personnel, and discusses successful coping mechanisms for such stressful situations..</excerpt>

title: Mental stress causes accidents, too.
doc: <title>Mental stress causes accidents, too.</title>

title: Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: I.
doc: <title>Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: I.</title>

title: The Eysenck Personality Inventory as a selection test for military pilots
doc: <title>The Eysenck Personality Inventory as a selection test for military pilots</title> <excerpt>As part of a study of the selection of candidates for pilot training in the Army Air Corps, EPI scores have been analysed in relation to success in training. Data from 432 AAC and 205 RAF student pilots have been examined.</excerpt>

title: Ergonomic aspects of aircraft keyboard design: The effects of gloves and sensory feedback on keying performance
doc: <title>Ergonomic aspects of aircraft keyboard design: The effects of gloves and sensory feedback on keying performance</title> <excerpt>Increasing requirements for aircraft keyboards have indicated inadequacies in ergonomic standards for airborne environments, in particular for tasks involving unskilled, discontinuous data entry, with emphasis on accuracy rather than speed. Four experiments are reported from a programme of research aimed at the development and application of methodologies for assessing factors relevant to keyboard design.</excerpt>

title: Conditioned feeding suppression in rats produced by cross-coupled and simple motions
doc: <title>Conditioned feeding suppression in rats produced by cross-coupled and simple motions</title> <excerpt>Conditioned feeding suppression was produced in rats by earth-vertical rotation, seesaw acceleration, and cross-coupled accelerations. Rats were exposed to 15 min of motion immediately after eating a sweet, novel food.</excerpt>

title: Recent life change measurement in Canadian forces pilots
doc: <title>Recent life change measurement in Canadian forces pilots</title> <excerpt>This study is the first in a series of steps aimed at developing a management tool that will provide a technique for screening accident-prone aviators. Because 'life change' is found to be a contributing factor to stress and development of illness in both civilian and military populations, the study of life change events in aviators is a reasonable point from which to begin.</excerpt>

title: Syncope in aircrew
doc: <title>Syncope in aircrew</title> <excerpt>In a study of 47 aviator patients consecutively referred to U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine for evaluation of alteration of consciousness, 34 cases of syncope were identified.</excerpt>

title: Airline pilot disability: Economic impact of an airline preventive medicine program
doc: <title>Airline pilot disability: Economic impact of an airline preventive medicine program</title> <excerpt>The current economic crisis facing most major United States airlines has forced a close examination of airline-sponsored activities. The effectiveness of one airline's pilot preventive medicine program was estimated by comparing disability experience of its pilots against the experience of a larger population of airline pilots.</excerpt>

title: Relative efficacy of the proposed Space Shuttle antimotion sickness medications
doc: <title>Relative efficacy of the proposed Space Shuttle antimotion sickness medications</title> <excerpt>Space motion sickness has been estimated as affecting between 1 3 and 1 2 of all space flight participants. NASA has at the moment proposed a combination of promethazine and ephedrine ( P E) and one of scopolamine and dextroamphetamine ( S D), both given orally, as well as a transdermally applied scopolamine (TAS), as preventive and ameliorative measures.</excerpt>

title: Some non-auditory correlates of the hearing threshold levels of an aviation noise-exposed population
doc: <title>Some non-auditory correlates of the hearing threshold levels of an aviation noise-exposed population</title> <excerpt>In a retrospective analysis of data collected during the 1963 followup of the NAMRL Thousand Aviator Study, two hearing level groups were identified, normal and impaired, and compared along 33 non-auditory dimensions. It was discovered that these two equally noise-exposed groups could be differentiated according to their smoking history and eye color.</excerpt>

title: Reasons for eliminating the 'age 60' regulation for airline pilots
doc: <title>Reasons for eliminating the 'age 60' regulation for airline pilots</title> <excerpt>The calendar age of 60 is no longer medically justifiable as an upper age limit for airline pilots. Advances in gerontologic studies, clinical medicine, and operational flight proficiency evaluations, now allow individual pilot assessments for health status and performance capability.</excerpt>

title: Air controller strike spotlights job stress.
doc: <title>Air controller strike spotlights job stress.</title>

title: Soviet space stress.
doc: <title>Soviet space stress.</title>

title: Italy's contribution, from a medical standpoint, to the space safety of payload scientists, and perspectives for the future.
doc: <title>Italy's contribution, from a medical standpoint, to the space safety of payload scientists, and perspectives for the future.</title>

title: Evaluation of a manikin psychomotor task
doc: <title>Evaluation of a manikin psychomotor task</title> <excerpt>A small, self-contained microprocessor displays a manikin on a TV screen in various orientations. Subjects are required to choose lateralities depending on a shape also presented on the display, and performance (accuracy and reaction time) is automatically recorded.</excerpt>

title: The psychosocial impact of a labour dispute
doc: <title>The psychosocial impact of a labour dispute</title> <excerpt>As a by‐product of a larger investigation, this paper examines the psychosocial impact of a 1976 labour dispute among Canadian air traffic controllers. Questionnaires were administered to the controllers during the dispute and during two subsequent periods of routine operations, four and 10 months later.</excerpt>

title: Sociological aspects of permanent manned occupancy of space.
doc: <title>Sociological aspects of permanent manned occupancy of space.</title> <excerpt>The author examines human experiences with isolation and confined groups to determine the sociological aspects of social isolation in space. Precedent experiences include Antarctic stations, oceanographic research vessels, submarines, undersea laboratories, and space simulators.</excerpt>

title: Application of signal detection theory to decision making in supervisory control the effect of the operators experience
doc: <title>Application of signal detection theory to decision making in supervisory control the effect of the operators experience</title> <excerpt>Signal detection theory (SDT) was used as a model for a supervisory activity: The decisions of the air-traffic controller using radar. Of particular interest was the 'professional-experience factor which was studied by comparing the performance of trainee and experienced controllers.</excerpt>

title: Biofeedback rehabilitation of airsick aircrew
doc: <title>Biofeedback rehabilitation of airsick aircrew</title> <excerpt>The biofeedback treatment of 20 aircrew, disabled by chronic severe airsickness, is reported. The USAF School of Aerospace Medicine (SAM) Airsick Rehabilitation Program requires careful selection to insure high motivation and thorough medical screening to rule out intercurrent medically disqualifying conditions.</excerpt>

title: The physician's determination of personnel reliability in sensitive occupations
doc: <title>The physician's determination of personnel reliability in sensitive occupations</title> <excerpt>The Air Force Medical Officer through AFR 35-99 (Personnel Reliability Program) is responsible for the medical evaluation, psychological assessment, and surveillance of persons who will work in sensitive occupations. This paper addresses various personality factors which indicate poor personnel reliability and suggest an interviewing technique of open-ended questions and developmental history assessment to help determine reliability.</excerpt>

title: Nursing peer review: A survey of flight nurse section members
doc: <title>Nursing peer review: A survey of flight nurse section members</title>

title: A computerized repository system for collection and retrieval of acceleration stress research data
doc: <title>A computerized repository system for collection and retrieval of acceleration stress research data</title> <excerpt>A data repository system for use in aeromedical acceleration research has been developed and is currently in use at the USAF School of Aerospace Medicine. The major functions of the repository include: a) increasing safety in human acceleration experimentation, b) documentation of clinical aeromedical evaluations, c) interface with management utilization systems, and d) rapid retrieval of data for analysis to enable a more in-depth understanding of +G(z) physiology.</excerpt>

title: Piloting when you 'should' be sleeping: What effects?
doc: <title>Piloting when you 'should' be sleeping: What effects?</title>

title: Psychiatric disability of Air Force fliers
doc: <title>Psychiatric disability of Air Force fliers</title> <excerpt>Case reports of psychiatric disorders in flying personnel tend to be reported in diagnostic clusters. When viewed separately, these reports suggest specific patterns.</excerpt>

title: Identification of features associated with flying phobia in aircrew
doc: <title>Identification of features associated with flying phobia in aircrew</title> <excerpt>The psychological and physiological features of 20 aircrew consecutively referred for treatment of anxiety symptoms when flying were compared with a matched control group of uncomplaining aircrew. There were no significant differences between the two groups on psychometric tests of personality, though there were differences in skin conductance; the phobics had a higher rate of spontaneous fluctuation, and habituated less to a repeated auditory tone.</excerpt>

title: Informational need of emotional stress
doc: <title>Informational need of emotional stress</title> <excerpt>According to the informational theory of emotions[1], emotions in humans depend on the power of some need (motivation) and the estimation by the subject of the probability (possibility) of the need staisfaction (the goal achievement). Low probability of need satisfaction leads to negative emotions, actively minimized by the subject.</excerpt>

title: Nausogenic properties of various dynamic and static force environments
doc: <title>Nausogenic properties of various dynamic and static force environments</title> <excerpt>Motion sickness can occur when an accelerating force acting on the human body repeatedly changes amplitude and direction or both. It also can occur without any motion after transfer into a constant force field significantly different from Earth-gravity.</excerpt>

title: Catecholamine excretion in A-10 pilots
doc: <title>Catecholamine excretion in A-10 pilots</title> <excerpt>Catecholamine excretion was determined for 15 USAF pilots during surface attack training in the A-10 aircraft. Timed urine samples were used to determine excretion rates of epinephrine and norepinephrine during basal conditions, during five sorties performed in high-realism simulators, and during six actual flights.</excerpt>

title: Toward the development of a new aptitude selection test battery for air traffic control specialists
doc: <title>Toward the development of a new aptitude selection test battery for air traffic control specialists</title> <excerpt>In an effort to update and refine the selection battery for air traffic controllers, five experimental tests measuring aptitudes and skills considered important in air traffic work were administered to 1,828 newly selected air traffic control specialist (ATCS) trainees on their first day of training at the FAA Academy in Oklahoma City. The five experimental tests and the five tests presently used by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) for selecting ATCS trainees were employed in an iterative stepwise regression (stepdown procedure).</excerpt>

title: Stress and adaptation: the interaction of the pilot personality and disease.
doc: <title>Stress and adaptation: the interaction of the pilot personality and disease.</title> <excerpt>This paper provides a descriptive backdrop for the assessment of the pilot in distress. Adaptation and stress are defined as the central paradigms for looking at behavior.</excerpt>

title: Serum cholesterol levels in selected air force cadets compared with levels in the West Point study
doc: <title>Serum cholesterol levels in selected air force cadets compared with levels in the West Point study</title> <excerpt>In the USAFSAM Cardiovascular Disease Followup Study, the surprising rise in average cholesterol levels in West Point cadets during the 6 years following their entry into the U.S. Military Academy in 1952 implied a significant increase in risk of heart disease in later years.</excerpt>

title: Human error in ATC system operations
doc: <title>Human error in ATC system operations</title> <excerpt>Air traffic control (ATC) system errors rarely occur in today's system. ATC-related aircraft accidents are even rarer events.</excerpt>

title: An information-processing interpretation of air traffic control stress
doc: <title>An information-processing interpretation of air traffic control stress</title> <excerpt>The air traffic controller's job is inherently stressful, resulting in a variety of stress-related symptoms and illnesses. Unusually high information-processing demands are placed upon controllers for extended periods of time, so that they often must work close to the limits of their channel capacity.</excerpt>

title: The measurement of the air traffic controller
doc: <title>The measurement of the air traffic controller</title> <excerpt>Measures of the air traffic controller are reviewed and critically assessed. There are many reasons for measuring the controller, and no measure can yet be treated as either indispensable or useless.</excerpt>

title: Occupational stress of intensive care nurses & air traffic controllers: review of related studies.
doc: <title>Occupational stress of intensive care nurses & air traffic controllers: review of related studies.</title>

title: Occupational psychology through autobiography: John Parry
doc: <title>Occupational psychology through autobiography: John Parry</title> <excerpt>The Journal of Occupational Psychology is publishing a number of invited personal accounts by psychologists who have made their mark on the history of the subject. This contribution is by John Parry, a pioneer in aviation psychology.</excerpt>

title: Investigation of life change as a contributing factor in aircraft accidents: A prospectus
doc: <title>Investigation of life change as a contributing factor in aircraft accidents: A prospectus</title> <excerpt>The author presents a personal perspective on attempts to reduce aircraft accidents resulting from human failure in the cockpit. The premise is that accidents result from an imbalance between performance ability and performance demand.</excerpt>

title: Laboratory performance during acute alcohol intoxication and hangover
doc: <title>Laboratory performance during acute alcohol intoxication and hangover</title> <excerpt>Eleven private pilots (seven men and four women) were recruited and trained on the Multiple Task Performance Battery (MTPB), static and dynamic tracking of a localizer/glide slope instrument, and use of the Intoxilyzer. Results showed clear deleterious effects of alcohol on the MTPB and the tracking tasks immediately following drinking.</excerpt>

title: Burning Out Versus “Punching Out”
doc: <title>Burning Out Versus “Punching Out”</title> <excerpt>"Burning out" among air traffic controllers is the syndrome of depression, anxiety, fear of a midair collision, insomnia, and inability to function professionally with confidence. Individuals who suffer such reactions are rapidly retired for medical reasons from air traffic control work.</excerpt>

title: Self-concept Changes Related to War Captivity
doc: <title>Self-concept Changes Related to War Captivity</title> <excerpt>A questionnaire was mailed to all US Air Force repatriated prisoners of the Vietnam war (POWs) still on active duty, and to matched controls, in the fall of 1976. Results were analyzed to determine long-term consequences of the war imprisonment experience.</excerpt>

title: Psychiatric education in aerospace medicine
doc: <title>Psychiatric education in aerospace medicine</title> <excerpt>In order to facilitate curriculum design for psychiatric education in aerospace medicine, three groups of physicians were surveyed: experienced flight surgeons, student flight surgeons, and psychiatrists trained in aerospace medicine. Two measures were obtained: 1) an assessment of the usefulness of particular psychiatric skills and knowledge in the practice of aerospace medicine, and 2) a rating of the clinician's abilities in these areas.</excerpt>

title: Hyperventilation in aircrew: A review
doc: <title>Hyperventilation in aircrew: A review</title> <excerpt>The causes and effects of hyperventilation, relevant to the flight environment, have been reviewed and one case history is presented. Methods of investigating in-flight hyperventilation are discussed..</excerpt>

title: Frequency analysis of heart rate variability under flight conditions
doc: <title>Frequency analysis of heart rate variability under flight conditions</title> <excerpt>The factors causing heart rate variability (HRV) were investigated under various kinds of workloads and flight conditions. Frequency analysis of heart rate, and cross-correlation analysis with blood pressure and respiration, were performed by using the fast Fourier analyser.</excerpt>

title: Coping with expanding nursing practice, knowledge, and technology
