Basic attributes of personality and motivation are of importance for military aviators to maintain optimal personal effectiveness, flying proficiency and safety in aviation.</excerpt>

title: Executive functions and pilot characteristics predict flight simulator performance in general aviation pilots
doc: <title>Executive functions and pilot characteristics predict flight simulator performance in general aviation pilots</title> <excerpt>In general aviation, 85% of the crashes seem to be caused by pilots' errors (Li, Baker, Grabowski, & Rebok, 2001) and 46% of the crashes occur at airports (Li & Baker, 1999). It is important to determine if the same factors influence the flying performance and the landing decision making and to uncover which factors, among the pilot's cognitive status, personality traits, and experience, are the most predictive.</excerpt>

title: Conceptions of cognition for cognitive engineering
doc: <title>Conceptions of cognition for cognitive engineering</title> <excerpt>Cognitive processes, cognitive psychology tells us, unfold in our heads. In contrast, several approaches in cognitive engineering argue for a shift of unit of analysis from what is going on in the heads of operators to the workings of whole socio-technical systems.</excerpt>

title: Chinese herbal medicine and cognitive and emotional functions during 60-day head-down bed rest
doc: <title>Chinese herbal medicine and cognitive and emotional functions during 60-day head-down bed rest</title> <excerpt>Introduction: This study aimed to test the efficacy of an oral-intake Chinese herbal medicine in enhancing the cognitive and emotional functions of individuals in a simulated microgravity condition. The herbal medicine consisted of ingredients that may enhance cognitive and emotional functions in an extreme environment.</excerpt>

title: Conflict-handling mode scores of three crews before and after a 264-day spaceflight simulation
doc: <title>Conflict-handling mode scores of three crews before and after a 264-day spaceflight simulation</title> <excerpt>Introduction: In both the Russian and U.S. space programs, crew safety and mission success have at times been jeopardized by critical incidents related to psychological, behavioral, and interpersonal aspects of crew performance.</excerpt>

title: Practical applications of UWB technology
doc: <title>Practical applications of UWB technology</title> <excerpt>Use of ultra-wideband (UWB) technology in various areas for remote sensing of the objects at short distances are considered. As an illustration UWB radar, in medicine and in psychophysiology, for remote measuring of patient's beating of the pulse and respiration is shown.</excerpt>

title: Personality traits in clinically referred aviators: Two clusters related to occupational suitability
doc: <title>Personality traits in clinically referred aviators: Two clusters related to occupational suitability</title> <excerpt>Background: The Five Factor Model (FFM) of normal personality provides a compelling framework for investigating personality subtypes in large military populations. The FFM was used to determine whether a sample of clinically referred military aviators exhibited commonly occurring personality clusters.</excerpt>

title: Cognitive function during acute cold exposure with or without sleep deprivation lasting 53 hours
doc: <title>Cognitive function during acute cold exposure with or without sleep deprivation lasting 53 hours</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Cold exposure and sleep deprivation are independently associated with transient cognitive impairment, including difficulty in attention, reaction time, and executive function. The possible interactive effects of cold exposure and sleep deprivation on cognition have not previously been examined.</excerpt>

title: Predicting professional success of air traffic control personnel from their personality profile at admission to Ab initio training
doc: <title>Predicting professional success of air traffic control personnel from their personality profile at admission to Ab initio training</title> <excerpt>The usefulness of personality measures for predicting air traffic controllers' (ATCs) performance in addition to cognitive aptitudes was tested using NEO Personality Inventory (NEO-PI) results of 60 ATC candidates at admission to the training. Extroversion (E) and its facets Gregariousness (E2) and Positive Emotions (E6) were valid and useful negative predictors of performance over and above cognitive ability level.</excerpt>

title: Behavioral and psychological issues in long-duration head-down bed rest
doc: <title>Behavioral and psychological issues in long-duration head-down bed rest</title> <excerpt>Introduction: This report is one of a series on the Flight Analogs Project, which is designed to lay the groundwork for a standard bed rest protocol. Behavioral health services, similar to those offered to the U.S.</excerpt>

title: Challenges in addressing graduate student impairment in academic professional psychology programs
doc: <title>Challenges in addressing graduate student impairment in academic professional psychology programs</title> <excerpt>Given the prevalence of emotional and psychological problems among professional psychologists, a primary concern to the field is impairment, or problems of professional competence. Graduate students, in particular, are an especially vulnerable subpopulation of mental health care professionals.</excerpt>

title: Ethical considerations when working with older adults in psychology
doc: <title>Ethical considerations when working with older adults in psychology</title> <excerpt>The growing number of older adults in America will result in an increasing demand for psychotherapists familiar with their psychological needs. To treat this population in an ethical manner, practitioners need to be aware of the unique characteristics of the aging process, especially in regards to age-related vulnerabilities, such as cognitive decline.</excerpt>

title: The ethics of psychology's role in politics and the development and institution of social policy
doc: <title>The ethics of psychology's role in politics and the development and institution of social policy</title> <excerpt>The relationship between psychological research and the development of social policy is controversial, as is any discussion of the role of values and morals within science. Three particular instances of this controversy are evident in psychological research conducted on affirmative action, child abuse, and abortion.</excerpt>

title: "MySpace" or yours? The ethical dilemma of graduate students' personal lives on the internet
doc: <title>"MySpace" or yours? The ethical dilemma of graduate students' personal lives on the internet</title> <excerpt>The booming popularity of the Internet, and particularly increasing use of personal Web sites, social networking sites, and blogging, raises questions regarding the ethical use of psychology graduate students' personal online information for academic purposes. Given rising controversies such as use of such information to screen applicants, I refer to the principles and standards of the Ethics Code of the American Psychological Association (2002) to examine ethical concerns associated with graduate students' personal information on the Internet, namely, the protection of privacy, use of informed consent, consideration of autonomy, and implications for students' clinical work.</excerpt>

title: Control of mobile robots using the soar cognitive architecture
doc: <title>Control of mobile robots using the soar cognitive architecture</title> <excerpt>This paper describes the development of a system that uses computational psychology (the Soar cognitive architecture) for the control of unmanned vehicles. A multithreaded software system written using Java and integrated with the Soar cognitive architecture has been implemented on two types of mobile robots.</excerpt>

title: Individual, work-, and flight-related issues in F-16 pilots reporting neck pain
doc: <title>Individual, work-, and flight-related issues in F-16 pilots reporting neck pain</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Neck pain is a common problem in F-16 pilots. A cross-sectional survey was used to determine the self-reported 1-yr prevalence of neck pain and to compare individual, work-related, and flight-related characteristics in F-16 pilots with and without neck pain.</excerpt>

title: Antarctic culture: 50 Years of antarctic expeditions
doc: <title>Antarctic culture: 50 Years of antarctic expeditions</title> <excerpt>Background: Analyses of data collected on returned Australian Antarctic personnel were conducted to examine links between personality traits, perceptions of Antarctic station culture, and perceptions of subjective fit with Antarctic station life and culture. Methods: Participants were 103 men who participated in Australian National Antarctic Research Expeditions (ANARE) over a 50-yr period from 1950 to 2000 representing the first 50 yr of ANARE and all positions and occupations included in Australian Antarctic expeditions.</excerpt>

title: Perceived brightness of incandescent and LED aviation signal lights
doc: <title>Perceived brightness of incandescent and LED aviation signal lights</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Aviation signal lights using light emitting diodes (LEDs) are commonly perceived as brighter than those using incandescent sources, even at the same measured intensity. In general, saturated colors, like those produced by LEDs, appear brighter than less saturated lights, like those produced by incandescent sources.</excerpt>

country: Canada - Norway - United Kingdom - United States
title: Psychological selection of antarctic personnel: The "SOAP" instrument
doc: <title>Psychological selection of antarctic personnel: The "SOAP" instrument</title> <excerpt>Introduction: The potential advantage of including a psychological test battery in the selection process for service in the Antarctic was examined in 348 applicants for employment in Antarctica with the British Antarctic Survey (BAS). Methods: Applicants were screened with the Selection of Antarctic Personnel battery (SOAP) consisting of nine well-known psychological instruments.</excerpt>

title: Thermal balance effects on vigilance during 2-hour exposures to -20°C
doc: <title>Thermal balance effects on vigilance during 2-hour exposures to -20°C</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Human mental performance is markedly affected by environmental temperature, body temperature, body heat content, and comfort, but the effects of these different factors are not entirely clear. A liquid conditioning garment (LCG) can be used to manipulate these factors independently.</excerpt>

title: Crewmember and mission control personnel interactions during international space station missions
doc: <title>Crewmember and mission control personnel interactions during international space station missions</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Reports from astronauts and cosmonauts, studies from space analogue environments on Earth, and our previous research on the Mir Space Station have identified a number of psychosocial issues that can lead to problems during long-duration space missions. Three of these issues (time effects, displacement, leader role) were studied during a series of long-duration missions to the International Space Station (ISS).</excerpt>

title: Personality influences on a two-man arctic expedition, impact on spouse, and the return home
doc: <title>Personality influences on a two-man arctic expedition, impact on spouse, and the return home</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Two men engaged in a kayak/sled Arctic expedition and their wives were evaluated. This report focuses on personality factors and decisions on the ice, psychosocial effects on those left behind, and the family re-integration process.</excerpt>

title: EEG correlates of task engagement and mental workload in vigilance, learning, and memory tasks
doc: <title>EEG correlates of task engagement and mental workload in vigilance, learning, and memory tasks</title> <excerpt>Introduction: The ability to continuously and unobtrusively monitor levels of task engagement and mental workload in an operational environment could be useful in identifying more accurate and efficient methods for humans to interact with technology. This information could also be used to optimize the design of safer, more efficient work environments that increase motivation and productivity.</excerpt>

title: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder: Treatment with sertraline, neuropsychological effects, and flight status
doc: <title>Premenstrual dysphoric disorder: Treatment with sertraline, neuropsychological effects, and flight status</title> <excerpt>Introduction: This case report reviews the aeromedical factors associated with considering a return to flight status of an aviator treated with sertraline 25 mg PO QD 5-7 d·mo-1 for premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). Particular emphasis is given to her performance on serial neuropsychological assessments while both on and off of the medication.</excerpt>

title: Ready or not: Enhancing operational effectiveness through use of readiness measures
doc: <title>Ready or not: Enhancing operational effectiveness through use of readiness measures</title> <excerpt>Current and future military operations require personnel to perform a multitude of mission tasks. Military personnel are required to execute these tasks, and to perform to high levels of expectation.</excerpt>

title: Skin temperature feedback optimizes microclimate cooling
doc: <title>Skin temperature feedback optimizes microclimate cooling</title> <excerpt>Introduction: A novel pulsed cooling paradigm (PCskin) integrating mean skin temperature (T̄sk) feedback was compared with constant cooling (CC) or time-activated pulsed cooling (PC). Methods: Eight males exercised while wearing personal protective equipment (PPE) in a warm, dry environment (dry bulb temperature: 30°C; dew-point temperature: 11°C) in each of the tests.</excerpt>

title: Antisocial personality disorder and medical certification
doc: <title>Antisocial personality disorder and medical certification</title> <excerpt>This case of Antisocial Personality Disorder (APD) highlights typical historical, physical, and test findings. For certification consideration, APD cases must be deferred to FAA's Aerospace Medical Certification Division.</excerpt>

title: The role of aeronautical adaptability in the disqualification of a military flyer
doc: <title>The role of aeronautical adaptability in the disqualification of a military flyer</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Possessing a stable personality plays a critical role in crew coordination, mission completion, and safety of flight in aviation. Presented is a naval flight officer whose personality traits were a threat to these key tenets and ultimately warranted removal from flight status.</excerpt>

title: Ultralight aviation accident factors and latent failures: A 66-case study
doc: <title>Ultralight aviation accident factors and latent failures: A 66-case study</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Little research has been done on ultralight aviation accidents. A better understanding of accident factors allows for better development of preventive measures.</excerpt>

title: Criteria that influence the choice of vocation - The use of Holland's method to optimize the process of selecting students for aviation studies
doc: <title>Criteria that influence the choice of vocation - The use of Holland's method to optimize the process of selecting students for aviation studies</title> <excerpt>The work contains the use of Holland's method to optimize the process of picking students to study aviation. In the first stage of research, scientific literature was analyzed.</excerpt>

title: Criteria that influence the choice of vocation–the use of holland's method to optimize the process of selecting students for aviation studies
doc: <title>Criteria that influence the choice of vocation–the use of holland's method to optimize the process of selecting students for aviation studies</title> <excerpt>The work contains the use of Holland's method to optimize the process of picking students to study aviation. In the first stage of research, scientific literature was analyzed.</excerpt>

title: Progress in the development of guidance strategies for the landing flare manoeuvre using tau-based parameters
doc: <title>Progress in the development of guidance strategies for the landing flare manoeuvre using tau-based parameters</title> <excerpt>Purpose – To provide a progress report into research conducted to establish guidelines for the development of guidance vision aids. Design/methodology/approach – The first stage of the research is to establish a coherent engineering basis for the methods of (visual) motion perception and control to inform the design of pilot aids that will support flight in degraded visual conditions, particularly when close to the ground.</excerpt>

title: Seat vibration in military propeller aircraft: Characterization, exposure assessment, and mitigation
doc: <title>Seat vibration in military propeller aircraft: Characterization, exposure assessment, and mitigation</title> <excerpt>Introduction: There have been increasing reports of annoyance, fatigue, and even neck and back pain during prolonged operation of military propeller aircraft, where persistent multi-axis vibration occurs at higher frequencies beyond human whole-body resonance. This paper characterizes and assesses the higher frequency vibration transmitted to the occupants onboard these aircraft.</excerpt>

title: Sex differences in tolerance to visually-induced motion sickness
doc: <title>Sex differences in tolerance to visually-induced motion sickness</title> <excerpt>Background: Women report a history of motion sickness (MS) about twice as frequently as men, but the results of experimental studies are equivocal. In the present investigation, we sought to replicate previous findings that women report a greater history of MS than men when interrogated with MS history questionnaires.</excerpt>

title: Luminous efficiency and the measurement of daytime displays, signals, and visors
doc: <title>Luminous efficiency and the measurement of daytime displays, signals, and visors</title> <excerpt>Purpose: Measurements concerning the usability or safety of optical equipment are based on assumptions regarding luminous efficiency. The current luminous efficiency functions are derived from human sensitivity experiments taken at low light levels compared with the outdoor day-time environment.</excerpt>

title: Wrist vibration affects the production of finely graded forces
doc: <title>Wrist vibration affects the production of finely graded forces</title> <excerpt>Introduction: It is still unclear how central commands and afferent feedback interact to produce finely graded forces. To explore this question, we experimentally degraded afferent responsiveness using wrist vibration.</excerpt>

country: Bahrain - China - Poland - Russian Federation - United States
title: Cross-cultural differences in psychosocial adaptation to isolated and confined environments
doc: <title>Cross-cultural differences in psychosocial adaptation to isolated and confined environments</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Differences in patterns of psychosocial adaptation under conditions of prolonged isolation and confinement in Antarctica were examined to determine the extent to which they were influenced by national culture in general and the individualist-collectivist orientation of national cultures in particular. Methods: The Profile of Mood States and measures of structural and functional social support were administered over an 8-mo period (March through October) to 13 winter-over crews from 5 nations operating research stations in the Antarctic: United States (3 crews, n = 77), Poland (3 crews, n = 40), Russia (3 crews, n = 34), China (3 crews, n = 40), and India (1 crew, n = 26).</excerpt>

title: Sopite symptoms in the optokinetic drum
doc: <title>Sopite symptoms in the optokinetic drum</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Sopite syndrome is a disturbance caused by motion characterized by drowsiness and mood changes that may occur without the classic symptoms of motion sickness. Because sopite symptoms are often subtle, it is important to assess for their presence, and to distinguish true sopite symptoms from changes in mood and drowsiness that are due to non-motion related factors such as fatigue and boredom.</excerpt>

title: Caffeine restores engagement speed but not shooting precision following 22 h of active wakefulness
doc: <title>Caffeine restores engagement speed but not shooting precision following 22 h of active wakefulness</title> <excerpt>Background: Current military missions occasionally require combat readiness of soldiers who might be experiencing a sustained period of activity without sleep. Strategies to overcome the debilitating effects of sleep deprivation include the ingestion of caffeine.</excerpt>

title: Stress and coping in a week-long disabled submarine exercise
doc: <title>Stress and coping in a week-long disabled submarine exercise</title> <excerpt>Background: Emotional stress could impair cognitive performance and decision-making in the initial period within a disabled submarine (SUBSUNK). The aim of the present study was to explore stress reactions over time in submarine crewmembers exposed to a simulated SUBSUNK trial.</excerpt>

title: Why people 'freeze' in an emergency: Temporal and cognitive constraints on survival responses
doc: <title>Why people 'freeze' in an emergency: Temporal and cognitive constraints on survival responses</title> <excerpt>Background: Many witnesses attest that victims of a disaster often perish despite reasonable possibilities for escaping because their behavior during the initial moments of the accident was inappropriate to the situation. Frequently witnesses report victims 'freezing' in the face of danger.</excerpt>

title: Selected Personality Characteristics of Student Naval Aviators and Student Naval Flight Officers
doc: <title>Selected Personality Characteristics of Student Naval Aviators and Student Naval Flight Officers</title> <excerpt>The Tridimensional Personality Questionnaire and the Hand Test were administered to 129 naval aviation student (79 student naval aviators and 50 student naval flight officer) candidates while they were waiting to begin basic flight training. Results indicated that, although pilot and flight officer candidate scores departed significantly in the same direction from normative data, there were few significant differences between the 2 groups on personality dimensions.</excerpt>

title: Affective reactions to and preference for combinations of interior aircraft sound and vibration
doc: <title>Affective reactions to and preference for combinations of interior aircraft sound and vibration</title> <excerpt>Affective reactions to the interior aircraft environment are a basic constituent of perceived ride quality. This study addresses affective reactions to combinations of interior aircraft sound and vibration.</excerpt>

title: Psychological testing/trait and group dynamics during 110-day in an isolated environment
doc: <title>Psychological testing/trait and group dynamics during 110-day in an isolated environment</title>

title: Speed-accuracy trade-off of grasping movements during microgravity
doc: <title>Speed-accuracy trade-off of grasping movements during microgravity</title> <excerpt>Background: Earthbound studies have shown that for pointing movements there is a specific relationship between movement speed, amplitude, and accuracy that is known as Fitts' law. We investigated the validity of Fitts' law for grasping movements in normal and microgravity.</excerpt>

title: Conscientiousness and work performance while suffering from acute mountain sickness: A case report
doc: <title>Conscientiousness and work performance while suffering from acute mountain sickness: A case report</title> <excerpt>A 52-yr-old male scientist who participated in a geophysical survey in Antarctica from a field camp located at 3538 m (11,600 ft) experienced specific symptoms of acute mountain sickness (AMS) by Mission Day 9, and full syndrome AMS by Mission Day 12. He was treated at the field camp and evacuated to sea level on the next available flight (Mission Day 15).</excerpt>

title: Psychological changes and group dynamics during confinement in an isolated environment
doc: <title>Psychological changes and group dynamics during confinement in an isolated environment</title> <excerpt>Purpose: Cultural and personal traits will become important as the number of short-duration spaceflights of international crews supporting the International Space Station (ISS) increases and more people begin staying aboard ISS for longer durations. This project investigated the interpersonal and personal changes of Japanese subjects during a 1-wk stay in the Japanese Experiment Module.</excerpt>

title: Evaluation of flexible cloth electrodes for electrodermal activity recording
doc: <title>Evaluation of flexible cloth electrodes for electrodermal activity recording</title> <excerpt>Background: Instrument selection for recording physiological data in flight studies requires careful attention to subject comfort and non-interference with aircrew activities. Several electrode types and recording sites may be used to examine electrodermal activity (EDA).</excerpt>

title: Crewmember and ground personnel interactions over time during Shuttle/Mir space missions
doc: <title>Crewmember and ground personnel interactions over time during Shuttle/Mir space missions</title> <excerpt>Background: Anecdotal reports from space and results from simulation studies on Earth have suggested that space crewmembers may experience decrements in their mood and interpersonal environment during the 2nd hall of the mission and that negative emotions may be displaced to outside monitoring personnel. Methods: To evaluate these issues, we studied 5 American astronauts, 8 Russian cosmonauts, and 42 American and 16 Russian mission control personnel who participated in the Shuttle/Mir space program.</excerpt>

title: Personality factors, stoicism and motivation in subjects under hypoxic stress in extreme environments
doc: <title>Personality factors, stoicism and motivation in subjects under hypoxic stress in extreme environments</title> <excerpt>Previous studies on the physiological and psychological adaptation of subjects to survival conditions involving high-altitude hypoxia (>6500 m) have shown that personality factors are important in this adaptation. We, therefore, proposed personality traits assessments in two groups of subjects engaged in sporting activities under extreme hypoxic environmental conditions: a group of mountaineers at high altitudes (>5500 m) and a group of free-lung divers at great depths (<30-60 m).</excerpt>

title: Behavioral science: A progress report
doc: <title>Behavioral science: A progress report</title> <excerpt>A prominent neuroscientist has recently observed that `More may have been learned about the brain and the mind in the 1990s... than during the entire previous history of psychology and neuroscience'.</excerpt>

title: Aircrew perceived stress: Examining crew performance, crew position and captains personality
doc: <title>Aircrew perceived stress: Examining crew performance, crew position and captains personality</title> <excerpt>This study was conducted at NASA Ames Research Center as a part of a larger research project assessing the impact of captain's personality on crew performance and perceived stress in 24 air transport crews (5). Three different personality types for captains were classified based on a previous cluster analysis (3).</excerpt>

title: Summary of research issues in personal, interpersonal, and group dynamics
doc: <title>Summary of research issues in personal, interpersonal, and group dynamics</title> <excerpt>People working on space missions, whether they are crewmembers or Mission Control personnel, must interact in groups. Consequently, it is important to consider interpersonal and group dynamic issues to assure that mission goals are accomplished.</excerpt>

title: Predictors of behavior and performance in extreme environments: The antarctic space analogue program
doc: <title>Predictors of behavior and performance in extreme environments: The antarctic space analogue program</title> <excerpt>Background: To determine which, if any, characteristics should be incorporated into a select-in approach to screening personnel for long- duration spaceflight, we examined the influence of crewmember social/demographic characteristics, personality traits, interpersonal needs, and characteristics of station physical environments on performance measures in 657 American men who spent an austral winter in Antarctica between 1963 and 1974. Methods: During screening, subjects completed a Personal History Questionnaire which obtained information on social and demographic characteristics, the Deep Freeze Opinion Survey which assessed 5 different personality traits, and the Fundamental Interpersonal Relations Orientation- Behavior (FIRO-B) Scale which measured 6 dimensions of interpersonal needs.</excerpt>

title: Antisocial personality: A case study
doc: <title>Antisocial personality: A case study</title>

title: The prediction of judgment in realistic tasks: An investigation of self-insight
doc: <title>The prediction of judgment in realistic tasks: An investigation of self-insight</title> <excerpt>Two approaches to policy-capturing research - mathematical and verbal - were compared to determine if flight instructors, psychology professors, and college football coaches evaluating "paper students" in profile booklets had self-insight into their judgment policies. Contrary to a widely accepted view that people lack self-insight, results suggested that many of the judges, particularly among the flight instructors, demonstrated self-insight; fewer professors and coaches showed self-insight as defined for this study.</excerpt>

title: Selecting pilots with crew resource management skills
doc: <title>Selecting pilots with crew resource management skills</title> <excerpt>For years, pilot selection has focused primarily on the identification of individuals with superior flying skills and abilities. More recently, the aviation community has become increasingly aware that successful completion of a flight or mission requires not only flying skills but the ability to work well in a crew situation.</excerpt>

title: The retention of adaptation to motion sickness eliciting stimulation
doc: <title>The retention of adaptation to motion sickness eliciting stimulation</title> <excerpt>Purpose: This study compared the retention of adaptation to motion sickness eliciting stimulation after 1 mo and 1 yr. Method: A total of 34 subjects who developed nausea to an optokinetic rotating drum in a preliminary session repeatedly viewed the same rotation with an interval of 48 h between sessions until they had no feelings of nausea.</excerpt>

title: Industry Application of Behavioral Science
doc: <title>Industry Application of Behavioral Science</title> <excerpt>One of the more significant errors in the history of science occurred during the "marginal revolution" in economics near the end of the nineteenth century. Rather than explicitly recognize in basic theory that the happiness we seek to maximize in life originates within oneself, the early theorists formulated their equations as though human satisfaction resided in external things - as in so much utility (economist's term for satisfaction) per pound of sugar.</excerpt>

title: Evidence that the slowing caused by acute hypoxia is modality dependent
doc: <title>Evidence that the slowing caused by acute hypoxia is modality dependent</title> <excerpt>Background: AFM (Additive Factors Method) experiments conducted with visual stimuli suggest that the slowing produced by acute hypoxia is located at the earliest preprocessing stage of information processing and that later stages are unaffected (the bottleneck hypothesis). Methods: To determine the contribution of degraded visual functioning to slowing, we bypassed this modality and measured reaction time in an AFM paradigm to auditory (Experiment 1) and kinesthetic (Experiment 2) stimuli.</excerpt>

title: Subjects perceptions of the crew interaction dynamics under prolonged isolation
doc: <title>Subjects perceptions of the crew interaction dynamics under prolonged isolation</title> <excerpt>Background: The interactions of individuals participating in space simulation studies can give us valuable information about ways that space crew members relate with one another. A promising method of investigating such interactions is based on the Kelly repertory grid technique.</excerpt>

title: Psychological studies of a Japanese winter-over group at Asuka Station, Antarctica
doc: <title>Psychological studies of a Japanese winter-over group at Asuka Station, Antarctica</title> <excerpt>In order to understand the psychological effects of Antarctic isolation and confinement on Japanese expeditioners, psychological studies were done on eight members of a wintering-over party at Asuka Station between December 1990 and February 1992. Mean age of the subjects was 34.8 ± 5.56 yr.</excerpt>

title: It is not how much you have but how you use it: Toward a rational use of simulatio to support aviation training
doc: <title>It is not how much you have but how you use it: Toward a rational use of simulatio to support aviation training</title> <excerpt>One of the most remarkable changes in aviation training over the past few decades is the use of simulation. The capabilities now offered by simulation have created unlimited opportunities for aviation training.</excerpt>

title: The psychophysiological assessment method for pilot's professional reliability
doc: <title>The psychophysiological assessment method for pilot's professional reliability</title> <excerpt>Background: Previous research has shown that a pilot's professional reliability depends on two relative factors: the pilot's functional state and the demands of task workload. The Psychophysiological Reserve Capacity (PRC) is defined as a pilot's ability to accomplish additive tasks without reducing the performance of the primary task (flight task).</excerpt>

title: The effect of autogenic training and biofeedback on motion sickness tolerance
doc: <title>The effect of autogenic training and biofeedback on motion sickness tolerance</title> <excerpt>Background: Motion sickness is characterized by symptoms of vomiting, drowsiness, fatigue and idiosyncratic changes in autonomic nervous system (ANS) responses such as heart rate (HR) and skin temperature (ST). Previous studies found that symptoms of motion sickness are controllable through self- regulation of ANS responses and the best method to teach such control is autogenic-feedback (biofeedback) training.</excerpt>

title: Crewmember interactions during a Mir space station simulation
doc: <title>Crewmember interactions during a Mir space station simulation</title> <excerpt>Background: Interpersonal problems may negatively affect crews on long- duration space missions. These problems stem from crewmember tension and its displacement to the outside monitoring personnel, and from disruptions in crew cohesion and unclear leadership roles.</excerpt>

title: Defining density altitude
doc: <title>Defining density altitude</title> <excerpt>When the elevation and the temperature rise, your airplane will develop a new and far more humble personality..</excerpt>

title: Psychological reactions during polar expeditions and isolation in hyperbaric chambers
doc: <title>Psychological reactions during polar expeditions and isolation in hyperbaric chambers</title> <excerpt>Background: Psychological data from environments that are considered as analog to space was collected from 68 subjects; 18 in hyperbaric chambers, 16 in polar expeditions, and 34 on Arctic stations. The objective was to identify psychological reactions expected in different phases of spaceflights and examine personality variables associated with superior adaptation.</excerpt>

title: Prediction of Situational Awareness in F-15 Pilots
doc: <title>Prediction of Situational Awareness in F-15 Pilots</title> <excerpt>Situational awareness (SA) is a skill often deemed essential to pilot performance in both combat and noncombat flying. A study was conducted to determine if SA in U.S.</excerpt>

title: Effect of sickness severity on habituation to repeated motion challenges in aircrew referred for airsickness treatment
doc: <title>Effect of sickness severity on habituation to repeated motion challenges in aircrew referred for airsickness treatment</title> <excerpt>The aim of this study was to determine whether varying the predetermined malaise level at which provocative motion challenges were stopped would affect the habituation rate. At the rate of 2 per day, 21 motion challenges were delivered, stopping either at initial symptoms or at moderate nausea, on a cross-over design randomized between subjects (n = 20).</excerpt>

title: Interpersonal relations during simulated space missions
doc: <title>Interpersonal relations during simulated space missions</title> <excerpt>The present article derives from two isolation studies performed for the European Space Agency (ESA) as simulations of space travels, lasting for 4 and 9 weeks. The aim was to study how interpersonal relations were affected by time, and how individual characteristics related to conflicts and tension among crewmembers.</excerpt>

title: A proposed profile of the effective leader in human spaceflight based on findings from analog environments
doc: <title>A proposed profile of the effective leader in human spaceflight based on findings from analog environments</title> <excerpt>This paper presents a literature review of leader characteristics and associated outcomes from four environments considered as analogs to long- duration spaceflight: aviation, submersibles, polar stations, and expeditions. Evidence from 23 sources indicates that, despite differences in the analog settings, effective leaders there a common core of personal traits and leadership-style attributes.</excerpt>

title: Factors influencing aeromedical decision-making: operational versus research environments.
doc: <title>Factors influencing aeromedical decision-making: operational versus research environments.</title> <excerpt>The aeromedical research and operational flying communities have at least one common goal; ensuring the optimum combination of mission performance and safety for the aircrew. This is a continual challenge as aerospace technology leaps ahead while the human factor remains relatively constant.</excerpt>

title: Assessing aviators for personality pathology with the Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory (MCMI)
doc: <title>Assessing aviators for personality pathology with the Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory (MCMI)</title> <excerpt>Psychiatrists independently evaluated 82 aviators referred to an aeromedical consultation service who had been administered the Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory (MCMI). The MCMI personality scales of those aviators psychiatrically deemed to be free from personality pathology were compared to the scales of those aviators psychiatrically assessed to have maladaptive personalities.</excerpt>

title: Seasickness susceptibility, personality factors, and salivation
doc: <title>Seasickness susceptibility, personality factors, and salivation</title> <excerpt>The present study investigates the possible relationship between motion sickness susceptibility, personality factors and salivation. Personality factors, as evaluated by the Eysenck Personality Questionnaire, and salivary composition and flow were measured in a group of 29 subjects highly susceptible to seasickness and in a group of 25 non-susceptible subjects.</excerpt>

title: Psychological evaluation of European astronaut applications: Results of the 1991 selection campaign
doc: <title>Psychological evaluation of European astronaut applications: Results of the 1991 selection campaign</title> <excerpt>In the summer of 1991, the European Space Agency (ESA) performed its second selection campaign since 1977 in order to find 10 astronaut candidates (laboratory specialists and space plane specialists). An integral part of this selection process was the psychological evaluation, according to the principles laid down in the study report 'Definition of Psychological Testing of Astronaut Candidates.' After national preselection, 59 applicants underwent the psychological evaluation, which consisted of the assessment of operational aptitudes (basic cognitive and psychomotor functions) and personality traits (motivation, social capability, stress resistance).</excerpt>

title: Astronaut psychiatric selection procedures: A Japanese experience
doc: <title>Astronaut psychiatric selection procedures: A Japanese experience</title> <excerpt>This paper presents the results of the first application of a structured NASA psychiatric interview for Japanese astronaut selection. We undertook a semi-structured, diagnostic, clinical psychiatric interview with 45 Japanese astronaut applicants for the position of mission specialist-astronaut, and performed 'select-out' psychiatric evaluations according to DSM-III-R psychiatric diagnostic criteria.</excerpt>

title: Predicting astronaut effectiveness: A multivariate approach
doc: <title>Predicting astronaut effectiveness: A multivariate approach</title> <excerpt>In this study, measures of astronaut effectiveness were administered to volunteers from the astronaut corps in order to validate psychological 'select-in' criteria for long-duration space missions. Using a peer nomination format, astronauts rated their peers with whom they had either flown or trained.</excerpt>

title: HIV-encephalopathy: should we await a catastrophe before screening?
doc: <title>HIV-encephalopathy: should we await a catastrophe before screening?</title> <excerpt>Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)-encephalopathy (formerly AIDS Dementia Complex, or ADC) is characterized by global impairment of intellectual and cognitive functions, personality and behavioral disturbances, decreased memory, inability to concentrate, and apathy. Its motor dysfunction is manifested by impaired speech, gait, and coordination, and by psychomotor retardation.</excerpt>

title: Psychological predictors of astronaut effectiveness
doc: <title>Psychological predictors of astronaut effectiveness</title> <excerpt>Are the personality characteristics of astronauts related to their professional effectiveness? In order to answer this question, effectiveness and personality data were collected from 65 NASA astronauts. Several findings emerged from these data.</excerpt>

title: The Construction of Personality Questionnaires for Selection of Aviation Personnel
doc: <title>The Construction of Personality Questionnaires for Selection of Aviation Personnel</title> <excerpt>The Personality Research Form (PRF), a questionnaire for voluntary self-description, was administered to a group of applicants (N = 300) for pilot training with a major European airline. Standard psychometric statistics were computed for the PRF subscales.</excerpt>

title: Age, circadian rhythms, and sleep loss in flight crews
doc: <title>Age, circadian rhythms, and sleep loss in flight crews</title> <excerpt>Age-related changes in trip-induced sleep loss, personality (n = 205), and the pre-duty temperature rhythm (n = 91) were analyzed in crews from various flight operations. Eveningness decreased with age (subjects aged 20-30 were more evening-type than subjects over 40).</excerpt>

title: Some personality and aptitude characteristics of Air Traffic Control Specialist trainees
doc: <title>Some personality and aptitude characteristics of Air Traffic Control Specialist trainees</title> <excerpt>This study examined the interrelations of personality traits, aptitude test scores, and job performance self-expectations as predictors of success in the FAA Academy screening program of prospective air traffic controllers. Based on the State-Trait Personality Inventory (STPI), men and women Air Traffic Control Specialist (ATCS) trainees exhibited less anxiety and anger than normative groups of college students and Navy recruits.</excerpt>

title: Assessments of astronaut effectiveness
doc: <title>Assessments of astronaut effectiveness</title> <excerpt>This study examined the reliability and convergent validity of three methods of peer and supervisory ratings of the effectiveness of individual NASA astronauts and their relationships with flight assignments. These two techniques were found to be reliable and relatively convergent.</excerpt>

title: Structured Interviews for Pilot Selection: No Incremental Validity
doc: <title>Structured Interviews for Pilot Selection: No Incremental Validity</title> <excerpt>An investigation of a structured interview for the selection of U.S. Air Force pilots was conducted on a sample of 223 pilot trainees.</excerpt>

title: Predictive Validity of an Automated Personality Inventory for Air Force Pilot Selection
doc: <title>Predictive Validity of an Automated Personality Inventory for Air Force Pilot Selection</title> <excerpt>A study was conducted to assess whether personality measures could contribute predictive utility to current Air Force pilot selection procedures. A personality inventory was given to a sample of 509 pilot candidates before flying training.</excerpt>

title: Analyzing Knowledge Deficiencies in Pilot Performance
doc: <title>Analyzing Knowledge Deficiencies in Pilot Performance</title> <excerpt>In the last decade, knowledge deficiencies and attitudinal problems have become recognized as the primary sources of pilot performance breakdown. This article presents an introduction to the five-dimensional professional performance analysis (PPA) system for analyzing and prescribing remedies to minimize pilot error and optimize pilot performance.</excerpt>

title: Success rate analysis of navy SERGRAD flight training
doc: <title>Success rate analysis of navy SERGRAD flight training</title> <excerpt>SERGRADS are selectively retained graduates of Naval Flight Training who become flight instructors during their first tour as Naval Aviators. A perception exists that SERGRADS have more difficulties than newly designated pilots during subsequent training in the Fleet Replacement Squadrons (FRS).</excerpt>

title: Psychiatric diagnoses aboard an aircraft carrier
doc: <title>Psychiatric diagnoses aboard an aircraft carrier</title> <excerpt>A descriptive study was conducted for 150 consecutive patients with a psychiatric diagnosis evaluated over 11 months by the medical staff onboard an aircraft carrier. Patients with sole diagnosis of alcohol abuse or dependence were excluded.</excerpt>

title: The Canadian Forces airsickness rehabilitation program, 1981-1991
doc: <title>The Canadian Forces airsickness rehabilitation program, 1981-1991</title> <excerpt>Airsickness is a significant obstacle in the training of some student pilots. When conventional therapy fails, desensitization therapy may be indicated.</excerpt>

title: Effects of dexamethasone and high terrestrial altitude on cognitive performance and affect
doc: <title>Effects of dexamethasone and high terrestrial altitude on cognitive performance and affect</title> <excerpt>This study examined the effects of dexamethasone and exposure to high terrestrial altitude on cognitive performance, affect, and personality. Cognitive performance was evaluated by five cognitive tasks, affect was evaluated by the Clyde Mood Scale and the Multiple Affect Adjective Check List, and personality was examined using the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory.</excerpt>

title: Psychosocial support for cosmonauts
doc: <title>Psychosocial support for cosmonauts</title> <excerpt>Based on a meeting with members of the Psychological Support Group for cosmonauts, along with several referenced documents, the author summarizes the Soviet experience in dealing with psychological and interpersonal factors related to long-duration space missions. Cosmonaut selection and training procedures following the principle of ''neuropsychological resistance'' formulated by F.</excerpt>

title: Cognitive changes at high altitude in healthy climbers and in climbers developing acute mountain sickness
doc: <title>Cognitive changes at high altitude in healthy climbers and in climbers developing acute mountain sickness</title> <excerpt>We report the cognitive functions of 17 non-acclimatized mountaineers who ascended from low lands to an altitude of 4,559 m in 24 h and were studied there within 6 h. We found that this rapid ascent to high altitude had small, but differential effects upon cognitive performance depending upon the later development of acute mountain sickness (AMS).</excerpt>

title: Habituation of motion sickness in the cat
doc: <title>Habituation of motion sickness in the cat</title> <excerpt>We subjected 30 female cats to a motion sickness stimulus in three series of tests. A series consisted of five tests given biweekly, weekly, or daily.</excerpt>

title: Relationships of anxiety scores to screening and training status of air traffic controllers
doc: <title>Relationships of anxiety scores to screening and training status of air traffic controllers</title> <excerpt>The present study assessed the relationship between anxiety, as measured by the State-Trait Personality Inventory (STPI), and success of post-strike air traffic control specialist (ATCS) trainees at the FAA Academy and during field training. The STPI was administered to students who entered the FAA Academy between June 1984 and September 1985.</excerpt>

title: The Impact of Personality and Task Characteristics on Stress and Strain During Helicopter Flight
doc: <title>The Impact of Personality and Task Characteristics on Stress and Strain During Helicopter Flight</title> <excerpt>A longitudinal research project on stress and strain of helicopter pilots engaged in low-altitude night flight with night vision goggles (NVG) was carried out over 3 years. An overview is given regarding the design and theoretical background of the project Psychological, physiological, and observational data were collected before, during, and after flight.</excerpt>

title: The measurement of psychophysiological reactions of pilots to a stressor in a flight simulator
doc: <title>The measurement of psychophysiological reactions of pilots to a stressor in a flight simulator</title> <excerpt>Seventeen Boeing 737 pilots were exposed to an acute stressor in a flight simulator: a birdstrike between V<inf>1</inf> (velocity of aircraft on take-off run at which crew is committed to take-off regardless of any incidents occurring) and V(R) (velocity of aircraft at take-off). Certain physiological variables together with state anxiety scores were measured at different stages of the simulated flight.</excerpt>

title: Community psychological effects following a non-fatal aircraft accident
doc: <title>Community psychological effects following a non-fatal aircraft accident</title> <excerpt>Following a non-fatal military aircraft accident, two of the authors interviewed the crewmen involved in the accident, their spouses, fellow squadron members and their spouses, and individuals from the fire crew and control tower on duty during the accident. A total of 37 respondents completed questionnaires which reported the presence of intrusive, avoidant, depressive/anxious, and post-traumatic stress symptoms.</excerpt>

title: Trends and individual differences in response to short-haul flight operations
doc: <title>Trends and individual differences in response to short-haul flight operations</title> <excerpt>A survey of airline pilots was undertaken to determine normative patterns and individual differences in mood and sleep during short-haul flight operations. The results revealed that over the course of a typical 2-d trip, pilots experience a decline in positive mood, or activity, and an increase in negative mood, or tension.</excerpt>

title: Influence of attitude and expectation on moods and symptoms during cold weather military training
doc: <title>Influence of attitude and expectation on moods and symptoms during cold weather military training</title> <excerpt>The present study examined the influence of the following: 1) air temperature, 2) day into training, 3) self rating of life stress, 4) rating of relative warmth in cold weather, and 5) expectation for liking cold weather training, on 59 soldiers' self-reports of illness and mood during 3 days of training in the cold (-18° to 0°C range). Mood was assessed on six domains of the Profile of Mood States rating scale, and symptoms of illness were assessed on 5 domains of the Environmental Symptoms Questionnaire.</excerpt>

title: Thresholds for the perception of whole body angular movement about a vertical axis
doc: <title>Thresholds for the perception of whole body angular movement about a vertical axis</title> <excerpt>Thresholds for the detection (at p = 0.75 correct) of the direction of discrete angular movements about a vertical Z axis, having a cosine bell velocity trajectory and a duration of 3.3 s, were determined using an adaptive psychophysical procedure. In 30 subjects the mean threshold for the detection of Z axis stimuli was 1.5 deg·s-1.</excerpt>

title: High-altitude mountaineering and brain function: Neuropsychological testing of members of a Mount Everest expedition
doc: <title>High-altitude mountaineering and brain function: Neuropsychological testing of members of a Mount Everest expedition</title> <excerpt>Concern has been raised regarding the possibility that hypoxic conditions encountered during high-altitude mountaineering may have lasting harmful effects on the human brain. Members of an expedition to Mount Everest completed a series of neuropsychological tests before and after the expedition.</excerpt>

title: Behavioral and physiological responses of stayers and quitters in underwater isolation
doc: <title>Behavioral and physiological responses of stayers and quitters in underwater isolation</title> <excerpt>Although the tolerance of subjects (Ss) to sensory isolation has been studied over the past 35 years or so, most attention has been paid to such variables as personality characteristics and less attention to physiological measures related to endurance. Additionally, the more profound isolation environment of water immersion has been much less studied than the quiet room environment.</excerpt>

title: Repeated exposure to moderate cold impairs matching-to-sample performance
doc: <title>Repeated exposure to moderate cold impairs matching-to-sample performance</title> <excerpt>To study effects of moderate cold (5°C) on complex cognitive performance, subjects were exposed to cold while responding on a conditional discrimination task. The task required a correct choice of which of two simultaneously presented matrices matched a previously presented sample matrix.</excerpt>

title: Adjustment of sleep and the circadian temperature rhythm after flights across nine time zones
doc: <title>Adjustment of sleep and the circadian temperature rhythm after flights across nine time zones</title> <excerpt>The adjustment of sleep-wake patterns and the circadian temperature rhythm was monitored in nine Royal Norwegian Airforce volunteers operating P-3 aircraft during a westward training deployment across nine time zones. Subjects recorded all sleep and nap times, rated nightly sleep quality, and completed personality inventories.</excerpt>

title: Interpersonal and group-behavior skills training for crews on space station
doc: <title>Interpersonal and group-behavior skills training for crews on space station</title> <excerpt>With the advent of space station, planners must come to terms with the inevitable psychosocial crew problems that accompany long-term confinement. Although some problems may be resolvable with the assistence of an on-board professional therapist-consultant, others can only be settled by whole-crew training in interpersonal, emotional-support, and group-interaction skills.</excerpt>

title: Low temperature worsens mammalian oxygen toxicity
doc: <title>Low temperature worsens mammalian oxygen toxicity</title> <excerpt>Oxygen toxicity was assessed in mice exposed to 5 ATA of oxygen. Central nervous system toxicity was measured as the latent period before convulsions, and lung damage estimated by wet and dry weight measurements.</excerpt>

title: Psychosocial training for physicians on board the space station
doc: <title>Psychosocial training for physicians on board the space station</title>

title: Mood states at 1600 and 4300 meters terrestrial altitude
doc: <title>Mood states at 1600 and 4300 meters terrestrial altitude</title> <excerpt>Personal anecdotes suggest that ascent to high altitude can cause mood changes such as depression, apathy, and drowsiness. Observed behaviors at high altitude indicate that people can become more euphoric, irritable, or argumentative.</excerpt>

title: The nature of sensorimotor adaptation to altered G-levels: evidence from mass discrimination.
doc: <title>The nature of sensorimotor adaptation to altered G-levels: evidence from mass discrimination.</title> <excerpt>Mass discrimination is impaired under zero G compared to 1 G. This is partly due to loss of weight information (a reduction in z-axis pressure stimulation), and probably also to incomplete adaptation to the reduced G-level.</excerpt>

title: A comparison of two methods of training resistance to visually-induced motion sickness.
doc: <title>A comparison of two methods of training resistance to visually-induced motion sickness.</title> <excerpt>This report concerns the use of two methods of training subjects to tolerate visually-induced motion sickness (VMS). Sixteen subjects were selected on the basis of their response to a motion sickness history questionnaire and assigned to one of four groups on the basis of their ability to tolerate visually-induced motion (VM).</excerpt>

title: Transfer of perceptual-motor training and the space adaptation syndrome.
doc: <title>Transfer of perceptual-motor training and the space adaptation syndrome.</title> <excerpt>Perceptual cue conflict may be the basis for the symptoms which are experienced by space travelers in microgravity conditions. Recovery has been suggested to take place after perceptual modification or reinterpretation.</excerpt>

title: Differential neuropsychological effects of diving to 350 meters
doc: <title>Differential neuropsychological effects of diving to 350 meters</title> <excerpt>Six divers were compressed on heliox to 350 m. Repeated neuropsychological and neurological tests were conducted during the dive.</excerpt>

title: Slow oscillations of psychophysiological parameters in human operators during monotony
doc: <title>Slow oscillations of psychophysiological parameters in human operators during monotony</title> <excerpt>Objective estimation of the human operator's functional state is an urgent problem in applied psychophysiology. It helps to forecast the reliability and efficiency of the operator's activity.</excerpt>

title: Thresholds for the detection of the direction of whole-body, linear movement in the horizontal plane
doc: <title>Thresholds for the detection of the direction of whole-body, linear movement in the horizontal plane</title>

title: Intraventricular conduction disturbances in flying personnel: Right bundle branch block
doc: <title>Intraventricular conduction disturbances in flying personnel: Right bundle branch block</title> <excerpt>The evolutive characteristics, as well as the qualification criteria, applied to 41 cases of complete right bundle branch block (CRBBB), detected in a presumably healthy population composed of 6,915 male individuals performing civil flying activities (prevalence = 5.9 per 1,000) were studied. In 17 cases, the CRBBB was detected in the first electrocardiogram (ECG).</excerpt>

title: Back to basics: suggested solutions to some flight instruction problems
doc: <title>Back to basics: suggested solutions to some flight instruction problems</title> <excerpt>Since 1976 a series of surveys of flight instructors and students in general and commercial aviation, and the Royal Australian Air Force, has indicated several common problems in flight instruction. These problems have provided a focus for instructor education programs described in this paper.</excerpt>

title: The stress of work: An overview
doc: <title>The stress of work: An overview</title> <excerpt>This paper looks at a number of potential occupational stressors found to predict job dissatisfaction and ill health (both mental and physical) in a variety of different occupational settings. Factors intrinsic to the nature of the job, role ambiguity and conflict, poor relationships at work, lack of career development, inadequate organisation structure/climate, and problems associated with the interface between work and homelife are the focal points of attention.</excerpt>

title: Off-vertical rotation produces conditioned taste aversion and suppressed drinking in mice
doc: <title>Off-vertical rotation produces conditioned taste aversion and suppressed drinking in mice</title>

title: The military performance of soldiers in sustained operations
doc: <title>The military performance of soldiers in sustained operations</title>

title: Motion sickness susceptibility in student navigators
doc: <title>Motion sickness susceptibility in student navigators</title> <excerpt>Identification of individuals highly susceptible to motion sickness could be of significant benefit in managing flying personnel in training. Several studies in the past four decades with this end have been primarily aimed at pilot trainees.</excerpt>

title: Ethical dilemmas and nursing
doc: <title>Ethical dilemmas and nursing</title>

title: Pointers to diagnosis of psychiatric illness in aircrew
doc: <title>Pointers to diagnosis of psychiatric illness in aircrew</title> <excerpt>Diagnosis of psychiatric illnesses in aircrew is made by assessing the symptoms complained of by the patient or observed by others. Symptoms should be matched against the textbook description of psychiatric disease: if the match is good, a diagnosis of psychiatric ill health is made.</excerpt>

title: Locus of control, self-serving biases, and attitudes towards safety in general aviation pilots
doc: <title>Locus of control, self-serving biases, and attitudes towards safety in general aviation pilots</title> <excerpt>Of the three related survey studies that were conducted, two are summarized and one, which characterizes all three, is reported in detail. The studies attempted to determine how aviators compared with the general population on the personality dimension - locus of control (internal vs external) and how this was related to aviators' attenance at FAA Safety Clinics.</excerpt>

title: The Wright brothers: a personality profile.
doc: <title>The Wright brothers: a personality profile.</title> <excerpt>Wilbur and Orville Wright were able, as a team, to develop the first heavier than air machine capable of sustained, controlled, powered flight while piloted by a man. This was due, very possibly, to the presence of a left hemispheric dominant personality in Wilbur Wright and a right hemispheric dominant personality in Orville Wright.</excerpt>

title: Neuropsychological functioning after prolonged high altitude exposure in mountaineering
doc: <title>Neuropsychological functioning after prolonged high altitude exposure in mountaineering</title> <excerpt>This prospective study examined the possibility of long lasting CNS sequelae of high altitude exposure in mountaineering. An extensive battery of neuropsychological and personality tests was given to 22 subjects before and after Himalayan climbs above 5334m (17,500 ft).</excerpt>

title: Reducing motion sickness: A comparison of autogenic-feedback training and an alternative cognitive task
doc: <title>Reducing motion sickness: A comparison of autogenic-feedback training and an alternative cognitive task</title> <excerpt>Eighteen men were randomly assigned to three groups matched for susceptibility to Coriolis motion sickness. All subjects were given six Coriolis Sickness Susceptibility Index (CSSI) tests separated by 5-d intervals.</excerpt>

title: Subjective response to negative air ion exposure
doc: <title>Subjective response to negative air ion exposure</title> <excerpt>This study investigated specific subjective or psychological effects of relatively long exposure to negative ions generated by a conventional air purification device. Subjects - 24 males matched for age, education, physical condition, and smoking habits - were divided into a control (N=12) and an ion exposure group (N=12).</excerpt>

title: Relationship of personality factors and some social habits to cardiovascular risk in submariners
doc: <title>Relationship of personality factors and some social habits to cardiovascular risk in submariners</title> <excerpt>Correlation and contingency analytical techniques were used to investigate the relationship between subtest scores on the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI) and coronary heart disease (CHD) risk factors in 1000 submariners. Groups of pesonality traits, both enhancing and protecting against risk of heart disease, were identified in these subjects.</excerpt>

title: Psychological testing at high altitudes
doc: <title>Psychological testing at high altitudes</title> <excerpt>Psychological testing was done on 20 subjects at various altitudes (sea level, 3,810 m, and 5,000 m) during a 35-d mountaineering expedition to Denali (Mt. McKinley).</excerpt>

title: Values clarification and the post-myocardial infarction patient
doc: <title>Values clarification and the post-myocardial infarction patient</title> <excerpt>Marked changes in an individual's attitudes and actions are frequently due to severe or prolonged conditions of stress. A stress encountered by the myocardial infarction patient is the anxiety or depression induced by the forced reduction of activities.</excerpt>

title: Prediction of success in a stressful career by personality attributes
doc: <title>Prediction of success in a stressful career by personality attributes</title> <excerpt>Several personality attributes were hypothesized to account for a part of the performance variability in continuous repetitive and real-stress situations. A Personality Inventory For Divers (PIFD) was administered to 518 divers and non-divers.</excerpt>

title: The effect of propranolol on human psychomotor performance
doc: <title>The effect of propranolol on human psychomotor performance</title> <excerpt>Despite their widespread usage the effect of beta blockers on human performance has been only sparsely studied and results of investigations are discrepant. This study examines the effect of one of the most commonly prescribed beta adrenergic blocking drugs, propranolol, on psychomotor function.</excerpt>

title: Minimizing the psychological effects of a wartime disaster on an individual
doc: <title>Minimizing the psychological effects of a wartime disaster on an individual</title> <excerpt>In this paper, the psychological reactions of individuals and groups to a wartime disaster, such as nuclear explosion, are presented. The psychological literature on disasters is discussed.</excerpt>

title: Comparison of two techniques for the development and maintenance of tracking behavior in monkeys
doc: <title>Comparison of two techniques for the development and maintenance of tracking behavior in monkeys</title> <excerpt>The present study compared two methods by which animal subjects can be taught to perform a pursuit tracking task. Rhesus monkeys were trained to track in order to avoid shock (Method #1) to obtain food (Method #2).</excerpt>

title: Psychological compatibility on Earth and in outer space
doc: <title>Psychological compatibility on Earth and in outer space</title>

title: Carbon monoxide and human time discrimination: Failure to replicate Beard-Wertheim experiments
doc: <title>Carbon monoxide and human time discrimination: Failure to replicate Beard-Wertheim experiments</title>

title: Performance, mood, and clinical symptoms in men exposed to prolonged, severe physical work and sleep deprivation
doc: <title>Performance, mood, and clinical symptoms in men exposed to prolonged, severe physical work and sleep deprivation</title> <excerpt>There were 44 young men who participated in strenuous combat courses of 4 d (course I) or 5 d (course II), almost without sleep. They were tested and examined clinically each morning.</excerpt>

title: Effects of ground trainer use on the anxiety of students in private pilot training
doc: <title>Effects of ground trainer use on the anxiety of students in private pilot training</title>

title: Some psychological correlates of motion sickness susceptibility
doc: <title>Some psychological correlates of motion sickness susceptibility</title> <excerpt>Four groups of 37 subjects each (highly susceptible men, highly susceptible women, nonsusceptible men, and nonsusceptible women) were obtained from a population of 2,432 college students ranging in age from 18 to 39 years. Susceptibility to motion sickness was determined by scores on a motion sickness questionnaire (MSQ); only individuals with extreme scores were considered for inclusion in the experimental groups.</excerpt>

title: Self rated moods of humans at 4300 m pretreated with placebo or acetazolamide plus staging
doc: <title>Self rated moods of humans at 4300 m pretreated with placebo or acetazolamide plus staging</title> <excerpt>Self-rated moods were determined twice daily with the Clyde Mood Scale on 35 human subjects at 200 m (baseline) during a study concerned with evaluating the efficacy of staging plus acetazolamide (treatment) for the prevention of acute mountain sickness (AMS). Mood states also were determined on all subjects at 4300 m (Pikes Peak, Co) and on 18 of these subjects at 1600 m (staging site).</excerpt>

title: Psychological considerations with patients on respirators
doc: <title>Psychological considerations with patients on respirators</title> <excerpt>Illness is a subjective experience for patients and, as such, responses to illness are as varied as the patients' personalities. Special psychological considerations are necessary when delivering care to patients on respirators since they, more than others, are dependent upon people and machines for each breath of life.</excerpt>

title: Analysis of the human voice as a method of controlling emotional state: Achievements and goals
doc: <title>Analysis of the human voice as a method of controlling emotional state: Achievements and goals</title> <excerpt>Background factors and those of formant structure, spectral and spectro temporal characteristics of rapid and slow speech components, temporal peculiarities, and intensity of speech turned out to be informative indices of the human emotional state. Application of mathematical methods, in particular methods of recognition theory, to these factors helped to assess the degree and the psychological sign of emotion, to diagnose the status of attention and fatigue, and to differentiate emotional and physical stress.</excerpt>

title: Some behavioral effects of pesticides: the interaction of mevinphos and atropine in pigeons
doc: <title>Some behavioral effects of pesticides: the interaction of mevinphos and atropine in pigeons</title> <excerpt>The interaction of the organophosphate mevinphos and atropine was examined in two pigeons performing in a variable interval schedule of reinforcement. When administered separately, both atropine and mevinphos produced a dose related decrement in responding.</excerpt>

title: Alpha index and personality traits of pilots
doc: <title>Alpha index and personality traits of pilots</title> <excerpt>This investigation was instituted to provide information regarding the relationship between individuals with radically different alpha indices (low vs high) and personality traits of the subjects. EEG recordings were obtained and acceptable diagnostic personality testing techniques administered.</excerpt>

title: Cross validation study of the personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents
doc: <title>Cross validation study of the personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents</title> <excerpt>Pilot error accidents have dominated accident statistics consistently from the 1940s to the present. In an earlier study the authors found that three factors from Cattell's Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire (16 PF) exhibited significant differences (p<0.05) between pilot error accident groups; these were used to correctly classify 86% of the aviators tested as to their previous pilot error accident involvement.</excerpt>

title: Psychologic and psychophysiologic response to 105 days of social isolation
doc: <title>Psychologic and psychophysiologic response to 105 days of social isolation</title> <excerpt>The responses of nine subjects to 105 d of social isolation are reported. The study reveals that crew selection plus ongoing support by psychiatric staff permits continued function in an exotic milieu.</excerpt>

title: Federal Aviation Administration's behavioral research program for defense against hijackings
doc: <title>Federal Aviation Administration's behavioral research program for defense against hijackings</title>

title: Assessment of seasickness and its consequences by a method of peer evaluation
doc: <title>Assessment of seasickness and its consequences by a method of peer evaluation</title> <excerpt>A Seasickness Questionnaire, based on a peer rating technique, was administered to 172 Israeli Navy sailors. Use of interrater agreement as a reliability index and 2 cutoff points for the partition of the sample resulted in the elimination of about 1/3 of the initial sample and the formation of 2 subsamples: the 'sick' (N = 45) and 'not sick' (N = 73) sailors.</excerpt>

title: Human factors in Air Force aircraft accidents
doc: <title>Human factors in Air Force aircraft accidents</title> <excerpt>Advances have been made in the design and reliability of Air Force aircraft; however, there continues to be materiel failure accidents. The design of man has not changed, although training programs have been improved to reduce accidents caused by human error.</excerpt>

title: Psychological characteristics of deep submergence vehicle personnel
doc: <title>Psychological characteristics of deep submergence vehicle personnel</title> <excerpt>The personality and developmental characteristics of US Navy Deep Submergence Vehicle (DSV) personnel, including operators and crews, were documented and compared to the characteristics of US Navy divers. The results show that DSV operators (DSV Oprs) had a significantly less asocial developmental pattern than divers, while developmental experiences of DSV crews (DSV Crs) were similar to those of divers.</excerpt>

title: Rat operant responding: an indicator of nitrogen narcosis?
doc: <title>Rat operant responding: an indicator of nitrogen narcosis?</title> <excerpt>One group of rats was stabilized on a variable ratio (VR) 50 schedule and another on a differential reinforcement of low rate (DRL) 20 s schedule. Four subgroups in each were exposed to 1, 7.1, 10.2, or 13.3 ATA for 30 min once a week for 6 weeks with a seventh exposure after a 4 week hiatus.</excerpt>

title: Personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents
doc: <title>Personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents</title> <excerpt>The consistently high frequency of pilot error accidents in both military and civilian aviation programs does much to support exploratory research which might help alleviate the problem. Cattell's Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire (16 PF), Mehrabian Achievement Scale, and a dynamic decision making task (under risk) were given to 51 Army aviators.</excerpt>

title: Personality makeup of the American air traffic controller
doc: <title>Personality makeup of the American air traffic controller</title> <excerpt>Based on scores from the Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire, the personality structure of 11,047 persons working as air traffic controllers, and 9886 persons applying for that job, was examined through factor analytic and analysis of variance techniques. It was concluded that air traffic controllers are superior to the general population in all characteristics of personality essential to performance of their work and, further, that applicants for these positions are even better qualified in certain respects..</excerpt>

title: Regularity in the control of the free running sleep wakefulness rhythm
doc: <title>Regularity in the control of the free running sleep wakefulness rhythm</title> <excerpt>The natural tendency of humans to lengthen their sleep wakefulness cycle in environments which minimize natural cues to time of day poses problems for designing efficient work schedules. In the present experiment, rigid control over the sleep and wake up times was employed in an attempt to contain the natural rhythm to a 24 h cycle.</excerpt>

title: Personality differences between male and female air traffic controller applicants
doc: <title>Personality differences between male and female air traffic controller applicants</title> <excerpt>Differences in personality structure between 9,886 male and 217 female applicants for air traffic control positions were examined, using the Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire. Data were analyzed through the analysis of variance, and factor analytic techniques.</excerpt>

title: Aircraft as an instrument of self destruction
doc: <title>Aircraft as an instrument of self destruction</title> <excerpt>Often the relationship between the pilot and his aircraft is such that the aircraft may be thought of as an extension of the pilot himself during the act of flight. If this pilot accumulates stress in his life with which he can no longer adequately cope, he may engage in self destructive acts, some of these within the context of his flying activities.</excerpt>

title: Social development of navy divers
doc: <title>Social development of navy divers</title> <excerpt>Ninety five U.S. Navy divers and 93 fleet controls, matched for age, rate, pay grade, and the age at which they joined the Navy, were compared for several important biographical characteristics.</excerpt>

title: Human performance at elevated environmental temperatures
doc: <title>Human performance at elevated environmental temperatures</title> <excerpt>A review of research on human performance at elevated temperatures is presented. The findings are analyzed in terms of 5 categories of performance measurements: time estimation; reaction time; vigilance and monitoring; tracking; and cognitive and other skilled tasks.</excerpt>

title: View of human problems to be addressed for long duration space flights
doc: <title>View of human problems to be addressed for long duration space flights</title> <excerpt>After 9,501 man hours in space, no physiological problems serious enough to cause lasting medical concern have been seen among U.S. astronauts.</excerpt>
